story:
A NOTE FROM THE DIRECTRESS

UN MOT DE LA REALISATRICE

 

 

It all started in 2015 when filmmaker Nathalie Pontalier invited me to write and direct the project she was producing in partnership with the National School for Hearing Impaired Children, which would be submitted to the film festival Sourd Métrage that had commissioned it. I was then surprised to find out there was a school for deaf children in Gabon because I had never met, studied or worked with anyone who communicates with sign language there. We gave weekly filmmaking classes to the 6th graders for 2 months and came up all together with a story for a narrative short, in which some of the teens acted while others assisted in different capacities.

Tout a commencé en 2015 lorsque la cinéaste Nathalie Pontalier m'a invitée à écrire et à diriger le projet qu'elle réalisait en partenariat avec l'École Nationale pour Enfants Déficients Auditifs, qui serait soumis au festival de cinéma Sourd Métrage qui l'avait commandée. J'ai été surprise de découvrir qu'il y avait une école pour enfants sourds au Gabon parce que je n'avais jamais rencontré, étudié ou travaillé avec quelqu'un qui communique avec la langue des signes. Nous avons donné des cours de cinéma hebdomadaires aux élèves de 6e pendant deux mois et nous avons créé une histoire pour un court métrage, dans lequel certains des adolescents jouait alors que d'autres assistaient dans différentes capacités.

 

 

I was instantly fascinated by the feeling of peace and serenity that bathed the workroom whenever I entered it, the easiness with which we all communicated —with the help of translator Ben Diawara Nziengui because speech reading is not taught to deaf people in Gabon, how seamless the classes ran and how, after the ice broke, inspired and talented the kids were. It quickly became obvious that they were naturally highly skilled for any visual activity, like learning a text, acting, photographing, styling, storyboarding, etc.

J'ai été immédiatement fascinée par le sentiment de paix et de sérénité qui baignait notre salle de travail chaque fois que j'y entrait, la facilité avec laquelle nous communiquions tous - avec l'aide du traducteur Ben Diawara Nziengui parce que la reconnaissance n'est pas enseignée aux sourds au Gabon ; la facilite du déroulement de nos cours, et comment, après la glace soit rompue, inspiré et talentueux les enfants étaient. Il est rapidement devenu évident qu'ils étaient naturellement hautement qualifiés pour toute activité visuelle, comme l'apprentissage d'un texte, le jeu d'acteur, la photographie, le stylisme, le storyboard, etc

 

 

After we wrapped the shoot, I knew I wanted to work more with the kids and their mentors. We had sat countless times sharing experiences while developing the screenplay for the short Telesourd together, drawing into personal experiences for storylines. We had so many more stories to tell. Moreover, knowing they had very few career options because of the lack of advanced education for hearing impaired people in Gabon, I was excited to offer them the possibility to build capacity in a field they had come to embrace and love, and that they could monetize in the future.

Après le tournage, je savais que je voulais travailler plus avec les enfants et leurs mentors. Nous avions partagé d'innombrables expériences tout en développant ensemble le scénario du court Telesourd, en s’inspirant d’expériences personnelles pour les scénarios. Nous avions tellement d'autres histoires à raconter. De plus, sachant qu'ils avaient très peu de choix de carrière en raison du manque d'éducation avancée pour les malentendants au Gabon, j'étais enthousiaste de leur offrir la possibilité de renforcer leurs capacités dans un domaine qu'ils avaient appris à aimer et à aimer, et qu’ils pourraient monétiser dans le futur.

 

 

I wanted to focus on themes around self-accomplishment and solidarity, to distance myself from usual topics of self-deprecation or victimization. I also wanted to craft a narrative that was intimate, to show the audience Gabonese individuals dealing with conflict, love, jealousy, rejection, greed, ambition.

So I centered the stories on each character’s personal experiences and the beauty that can come from their dire circumstances.

Je voulais me concentrer sur des thèmes autour de l'auto-accomplissement et de la solidarité, pour m'éloigner des sujets habituels d'auto-dépréciation ou de victimisation. Je voulais aussi faire un récit intime, pour montrer au public gabonais des individus aux prises avec le conflit, l'amour, la jalousie, le rejet, la cupidité, l'ambition.


Donc, j'ai centré les histoires sur les expériences personnelles de chaque personnage et la beauté qui peut venir de leurs circonstances désastreuses.

 

 

Training and sharing knowledge being the cornerstone, we crewed up students or young graduates for the assistant’s positions. The visual style I created with my Cinematographer Puntcho Bagnet and my Set Designer Malanda Loumouamou had to reflect the spirit of the project and channel the hope I wanted to infuse in it. I also wanted the story to be easily accessible to a broad and young audience, which meant fast-paced and catchy.

La formation et le partage des connaissances étant la pierre angulaire, nous avons fait équipe avec des étudiants ou de jeunes diplômés pour les postes d'assistants. Le style visuel que j'ai créé avec mon directeur de la photographie Puntcho Bagnet et ma scénographe Malanda Loumouamou devait refléter l'esprit du projet et canaliser l'espoir que je souhaitais y insuffler. Je voulais aussi que l'histoire soit facilement accessible à un public large et jeune, ce qui signifiait un rythme rapide et accrocheur.

 

 

We spent 19 days shooting in the Libreville and somehow pulled off an amazing feat of Independent filmmaking. Now we want to invite you into the process to help us finish the film.

Nous avons passé 19 jours à tourner à Libreville et avons réussi à faire un exploit incroyable de cinéma indépendant. Maintenant, nous voulons vous inviter dans le processus pour nous aider à terminer le film.

 

USE OF FUNDS

UTILISATION DES FONDS

 

Editing

Color grading and correction

Visual effects

Music Composition 

Securing music rights

Sound effects and Sound mix

Marketing and Film Festival expenses



Montage

Etalonnage

Effets visuels

Composition musicale

Sécurisation des musicaux

Effets sonores et Mixage sonore

Frais de marketing et de festivals

 

 

 

We have some great rewards for those who are able to give. Check out the list below!

Nous avons de super récompenses pour ceux qui peuvent  donner. Voir la liste ci-dessous!

 

REWARDS

RECOMPENSES

 

$10 -End Credits "Thank You" list

$10 -Remerciements au générique de fin

$20 -Digital Download – Sens Dessus Dessous

$20 -Téléchargement Digital – Sens Dessus Dessous

$30 - Digital Playlist Curated by Daddy aka Arel Mekindet

$30 - Playlist Digital par Daddy aka Arel Mekindet

$50 - Sens Dessus Dessous – POSTCARD

$50 - Sens Dessus Dessous – CARTE POSTALE

$100 - Sens Dessus Dessous – TOTE BAG

$100 - Sens Dessus Dessous – SAC FOURRE TOUT

 

$300 - Stream Sens Dessus Dessous Soundtrack

$300 - Streaming de la bande originale de Sens Dessus Dessous

$500 - Signed Print Still Photography 8” x 10” from the Making Of Sens Dessus Dessous

$500 - Photo signée du Making Of de Sens Dessus Dessous

$1,000 - Associate Producer Credit

$1,000 - Mention Producteur Associé au générique

$2,500 - Executive Producer Credit

$2,500 - Mention Producteur Exécutif au générique

$5,000 - Private Screening & Executive Producer

$5,000 - Projection Priveée & Mention Producteur Exécutif au générique

 

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help: please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Simply use the Indiegogo share tools.

THANK YOU!!!

 

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer, cela ne signifie pas que vous ne pouvez pas aider: s'il vous plaît faites passer le mot et faites du bruit sur ma campagne. Utilisez simplement les outils de partage Indiegogo.

JE VOUS REMERCIE!!!

 

 

Video shot by Kiritin Beyer, Edited by Bohdana Smyrnova

Still photography by Arel Mekindet, Ben Diawara Nziengui, IceMan and Malanda Loumouamou

 

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

RISQUES ET DEFIS

 

I was quite green when I embarked on this project, never having produced my own work. Funding turned out to be the most challenging part. I realized investors were not interested in financing Gabonese films that weren’t either self-deprecating comedy or sorcery-steeped drama. We could get into production thanks to a generous donation from the charitable organization Lyons Club Hibiscus, a contribution from the art sponsor beverage distributor Sobraga (against product placement), breakfasts thanks to L'Escale Royale and self-financing. I had to leverage my producer career and invested all of my income to raise the minimum required for the series. After 2 years, we succeeded in producing great stories of collective accomplishment in Gabon but we need your help to finish it and bring it to your screens around the world. Thank you!

J'étais assez débutante quand je me suis lancée dans ce projet, n'ayant jamais produit mon propre travail. Le financement s'est avéré être la partie la plus difficile. J'ai réalisé que les investisseurs n'étaient pas intéressés par le financement de films gabonais qui n'étaient ni des comédies autoderisoires, ni des drames imprégnés de sorcellerie. Nous avons pu entrer en production grâce à un don généreux de l'association caritative Lyons Club Hibiscus, une contribution du distributeur de boissons Sobraga (contre le placement de produits), des petits déjeuners fournit par L'Escale Royale et un autofinancement. J'ai dû tirer parti de ma carrière de producteur et investir tout mes revenus pour assurer le minimum requis pour la série. Après 2 ans, nous avons réussi à produire de grandes histoires d'accomplissement collectif au Gabon mais nous avons besoin de votre aide pour le finir et l'amener sur vos écrans à travers le monde. Je vous remercie!
story_txt: A NOTE FROM THE DIRECTRESSUN MOT DE LA REALISATRICE  It all started in 2015 when filmmaker Nathalie Pontalier invited me to write and direct the project she was producing in partnership with the National School for Hearing Impaired Children, which would be submitted to the film festival Sourd Métrage that had commissioned it. I was then surprised to find out there was a school for deaf children in Gabon because I had never met, studied or worked with anyone who communicates with sign language there. We gave weekly filmmaking classes to the 6th graders for 2 months and came up all together with a story for a narrative short, in which some of the teens acted while others assisted in different capacities.Tout a commencé en 2015 lorsque la cinéaste Nathalie Pontalier m'a invitée à écrire et à diriger le projet qu'elle réalisait en partenariat avec l'École Nationale pour Enfants Déficients Auditifs, qui serait soumis au festival de cinéma Sourd Métrage qui l'avait commandée. J'ai été surprise de découvrir qu'il y avait une école pour enfants sourds au Gabon parce que je n'avais jamais rencontré, étudié ou travaillé avec quelqu'un qui communique avec la langue des signes. Nous avons donné des cours de cinéma hebdomadaires aux élèves de 6e pendant deux mois et nous avons créé une histoire pour un court métrage, dans lequel certains des adolescents jouait alors que d'autres assistaient dans différentes capacités.  I was instantly fascinated by the feeling of peace and serenity that bathed the workroom whenever I entered it, the easiness with which we all communicated —with the help of translator Ben Diawara Nziengui because speech reading is not taught to deaf people in Gabon, how seamless the classes ran and how, after the ice broke, inspired and talented the kids were. It quickly became obvious that they were naturally highly skilled for any visual activity, like learning a text, acting, photographing, styling, storyboarding, etc.J'ai été immédiatement fascinée par le sentiment de paix et de sérénité qui baignait notre salle de travail chaque fois que j'y entrait, la facilité avec laquelle nous communiquions tous - avec l'aide du traducteur Ben Diawara Nziengui parce que la reconnaissance n'est pas enseignée aux sourds au Gabon ; la facilite du déroulement de nos cours, et comment, après la glace soit rompue, inspiré et talentueux les enfants étaient. Il est rapidement devenu évident qu'ils étaient naturellement hautement qualifiés pour toute activité visuelle, comme l'apprentissage d'un texte, le jeu d'acteur, la photographie, le stylisme, le storyboard, etc  After we wrapped the shoot, I knew I wanted to work more with the kids and their mentors. We had sat countless times sharing experiences while developing the screenplay for the short Telesourd together, drawing into personal experiences for storylines. We had so many more stories to tell. Moreover, knowing they had very few career options because of the lack of advanced education for hearing impaired people in Gabon, I was excited to offer them the possibility to build capacity in a field they had come to embrace and love, and that they could monetize in the future.Après le tournage, je savais que je voulais travailler plus avec les enfants et leurs mentors. Nous avions partagé d'innombrables expériences tout en développant ensemble le scénario du court Telesourd, en s’inspirant d’expériences personnelles pour les scénarios. Nous avions tellement d'autres histoires à raconter. De plus, sachant qu'ils avaient très peu de choix de carrière en raison du manque d'éducation avancée pour les malentendants au Gabon, j'étais enthousiaste de leur offrir la possibilité de renforcer leurs capacités dans un domaine qu'ils avaient appris à aimer et à aimer, et qu’ils pourraient monétiser dans le futur.  I wanted to focus on themes around self-accomplishment and solidarity, to distance myself from usual topics of self-deprecation or victimization. I also wanted to craft a narrative that was intimate, to show the audience Gabonese individuals dealing with conflict, love, jealousy, rejection, greed, ambition.So I centered the stories on each character’s personal experiences and the beauty that can come from their dire circumstances.Je voulais me concentrer sur des thèmes autour de l'auto-accomplissement et de la solidarité, pour m'éloigner des sujets habituels d'auto-dépréciation ou de victimisation. Je voulais aussi faire un récit intime, pour montrer au public gabonais des individus aux prises avec le conflit, l'amour, la jalousie, le rejet, la cupidité, l'ambition.Donc, j'ai centré les histoires sur les expériences personnelles de chaque personnage et la beauté qui peut venir de leurs circonstances désastreuses.  Training and sharing knowledge being the cornerstone, we crewed up students or young graduates for the assistant’s positions. The visual style I created with my Cinematographer Puntcho Bagnet and my Set Designer Malanda Loumouamou had to reflect the spirit of the project and channel the hope I wanted to infuse in it. I also wanted the story to be easily accessible to a broad and young audience, which meant fast-paced and catchy.La formation et le partage des connaissances étant la pierre angulaire, nous avons fait équipe avec des étudiants ou de jeunes diplômés pour les postes d'assistants. Le style visuel que j'ai créé avec mon directeur de la photographie Puntcho Bagnet et ma scénographe Malanda Loumouamou devait refléter l'esprit du projet et canaliser l'espoir que je souhaitais y insuffler. Je voulais aussi que l'histoire soit facilement accessible à un public large et jeune, ce qui signifiait un rythme rapide et accrocheur.  We spent 19 days shooting in the Libreville and somehow pulled off an amazing feat of Independent filmmaking. Now we want to invite you into the process to help us finish the film.Nous avons passé 19 jours à tourner à Libreville et avons réussi à faire un exploit incroyable de cinéma indépendant. Maintenant, nous voulons vous inviter dans le processus pour nous aider à terminer le film. USE OF FUNDSUTILISATION DES FONDS EditingColor grading and correctionVisual effectsMusic Composition Securing music rightsSound effects and Sound mixMarketing and Film Festival expensesMontageEtalonnage Effets visuelsComposition musicaleSécurisation des musicauxEffets sonores et Mixage sonoreFrais de marketing et de festivals   We have some great rewards for those who are able to give. Check out the list below!Nous avons de super récompenses pour ceux qui peuvent  donner. Voir la liste ci-dessous! REWARDSRECOMPENSES $10 -End Credits "Thank You" list$10 -Remerciements au générique de fin$20 -Digital Download – Sens Dessus Dessous$20 -Téléchargement Digital – Sens Dessus Dessous$30 - Digital Playlist Curated by Daddy aka Arel Mekindet$30 - Playlist Digital par Daddy aka Arel Mekindet$50 - Sens Dessus Dessous – POSTCARD$50 - Sens Dessus Dessous – CARTE POSTALE$100 - Sens Dessus Dessous – TOTE BAG$100 - Sens Dessus Dessous – SAC FOURRE TOUT $300 - Stream Sens Dessus Dessous Soundtrack$300 - Streaming de la bande originale de Sens Dessus Dessous $500 - Signed Print Still Photography 8” x 10” from the Making Of Sens Dessus Dessous$500 - Photo signée du Making Of de Sens Dessus Dessous$1,000 - Associate Producer Credit$1,000 - Mention Producteur Associé au générique $2,500 - Executive Producer Credit$2,500 - Mention Producteur Exécutif au générique$5,000 - Private Screening & Executive Producer$5,000 - Projection Priveée & Mention Producteur Exécutif au générique If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help: please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Simply use the Indiegogo share tools.THANK YOU!!! Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer, cela ne signifie pas que vous ne pouvez pas aider: s'il vous plaît faites passer le mot et faites du bruit sur ma campagne. Utilisez simplement les outils de partage Indiegogo.JE VOUS REMERCIE!!!  Video shot by Kiritin Beyer, Edited by Bohdana SmyrnovaStill photography by Arel Mekindet, Ben Diawara Nziengui, IceMan and Malanda Loumouamou  RISKS AND CHALLENGESRISQUES ET DEFIS I was quite green when I embarked on this project, never having produced my own work. Funding turned out to be the most challenging part. I realized investors were not interested in financing Gabonese films that weren’t either self-deprecating comedy or sorcery-steeped drama. We could get into production thanks to a generous donation from the charitable organization Lyons Club Hibiscus, a contribution from the art sponsor beverage distributor Sobraga (against product placement), breakfasts thanks to L'Escale Royale and self-financing. I had to leverage my producer career and invested all of my income to raise the minimum required for the series. After 2 years, we succeeded in producing great stories of collective accomplishment in Gabon but we need your help to finish it and bring it to your screens around the world. Thank you!J'étais assez débutante quand je me suis lancée dans ce projet, n'ayant jamais produit mon propre travail. Le financement s'est avéré être la partie la plus difficile. J'ai réalisé que les investisseurs n'étaient pas intéressés par le financement de films gabonais qui n'étaient ni des comédies autoderisoires, ni des drames imprégnés de sorcellerie. Nous avons pu entrer en production grâce à un don généreux de l'association caritative Lyons Club Hibiscus, une contribution du distributeur de boissons Sobraga (contre le placement de produits), des petits déjeuners fournit par L'Escale Royale et un autofinancement. J'ai dû tirer parti de ma carrière de producteur et investir tout mes revenus pour assurer le minimum requis pour la série. Après 2 ans, nous avons réussi à produire de grandes histoires d'accomplissement collectif au Gabon mais nous avons besoin de votre aide pour le finir et l'amener sur vos écrans à travers le monde. Je vous remercie!

story:
www.rinkwester.com

 

 

For my cohorts in China who might not get the english this is for you crazy kids:

如果你们还有什么看不懂的问题请联系我们的亚洲地区制片人Stanley Xiao: stanley0733@outlook.com

（上面的预告片的视频是Youtube的所以在中国你恩可能打不开。请联系Stanley Xiao然后他可以直接给你发过去！）

 

 

 

Howdy Folks!

Rink Wester and the Rink Wester 726 Foundation Studios here!

We’ve been waiting and yearning and pining to do this, and now the time has come. The novels have been a blockbuster success worldwide, our script is written and we’re getting all antsy in our pantsy to start shooting. There’s just one problem:

While the studio has given us tentative permission to start our film series journey, and agreed to distribute it (at least in the USA and Canada) and to foot 50% of the total filming and production cost, we need to fund the rest of the movie ourselves. (Bummer! I know!)

Enter: YOU!

So this is how it works: if we’re able to raise at least $2,000,000 in the next month, we’ll be able to get to work on a barebones version of "Of The Dark and The Deep" (the first film in the series) this summer. But $2,000,000 is the bare minimum we’ll need to get into production.

Rink Wester (Hi again...yeah...that's me!) is investing $750,000 of his own money (Whew! Lord have mercy!)  while The Studio has graciously agreed to invest $1 Million ('Dere is a Gawd Somewhere!) and the final $250,000, as they say, IS UP TO YOU! 

We’ve got some big stuff in the script, and if we’re able to raise enough money, you’ll get to see all of it. The more we raise, the more amazing stuff we can put in the movie. More magyck, more epic god and wizard battles, sexy action, more famous actor cameos, more film shenanigans, and just...MORE!

And here’s the other thing: to give OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP a wider release – that is, to get it into a theater near YOU – we need to prove that there’s a real demand to see it, and not just a dozen stoned out Wiccans who keep asking for it over and over (I love you Wiccans! Truly I do!).

That means: the more people who contribute to help make the movie, the better our chances of getting a wide release, and coming to a theater where you can enjoy the magykal world of Hikorim and the gods of the Ogdoad living in Atlanta in their full, cinematic splendor.

P.S. Tiffany Haddish...please call us girl!!!! We heard you love Sci-Fi, Fantasy and Magyck and there is always a role here for you boo!!!!!

Now can we talk about what you really want to know? We know that aside from a powerful action packed sci-fi/fantasy movie, you also want some cool perks. Well, our perks are so good they might change your social, emotional, sexual, religious and political views. (Yep! Just that good!)

If you help us get it made now, you shouldn’t have to pay again to see it later. Whatever you contribute now doesn’t just go into someone’s pocket as profit: it lets us make a better movie for you. Why wait and pay later with the rest of the crowd? Most of our perk packages let you see the  movie you helped produce when it comes out: get Fandango Movie Tickets ($35 package and above), DVDs and Blu-Rays ($150 package and above), and add the digital download as an add-on (just $30).

It’s your movie too, so you should be able to share the experience. You’re the reason we’ve knocked down walls and bent the knee any and everywhere we could trying to make this movie, and you’re the reason we’ll get to make it now, so we want you rookie gøds, wizards, witches, warlocks, elves, orcs, fairies (you know who you are girl!) sprites, demons, angels, atheist warlords, girl scouts and mailmen to be right in there with us. We’ve got big plans for behind-the-scenes access, and our perks include actual producer credits, movie equity, set visits, chances to be in the movie, tickets to an exclusive advance screening tour, or even to join us at one of the red carpet premieres and afterparties! We’ll show you how the Rink Wester 726 Studio makes a movie.  It might get weird. (But you'll love it! Admit it...you  like it a little weird, doncha'!)

We want to hang out with you folks.  We love getting to chill with you wherever you are in the world. So we’ve got some fun stuff planned for the next 6 months (But only if we reach our goal!)

Join us in a private luxury box to catch a baseball/football/basketball game, or meet up with us in Atlanta or DC to grab some chicken/waffles/beer/wine/corn liquor and pancakes or for the brave, come drink against us at our first ever Rink Wester Winefest Tournament. We’ll kick your ass, but we’ll respect you in the morning.

And for our top contributors, we’re willing to go that extra mile.

Take over our set. Want to hang out behind the camera and help Rink Wester direct? We’ll let you call action. Prefer to pad out your IMDB page with an on-screen credit as one of our producers? Done. Prefer to be in front of the camera? We’ve got a speaking line with your name on it. (That’s right: we’re offering the chance to be in OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP!That’s how serious we are!!!)

We’ll come to you. That’s right. Kick back, relax, and forget about the hassles of travel: we’ll get on a plane and come to you. Have us organize a private reading/concert/winetasting  show for you and your 25 closest friends. Or invite us to your wedding, and I/We will join you at the altar as your groomsmen (or bridesmaids, ladies, if you prefer).

For you hardcore magyck enthusiasts receive a real custom handmade Michael Amini Victoria Palace platinum and gold plated Wand and magyckal Elven Staff hewn from pure blessed African Sandalwood (This wood is $20,000 a kilo y'all! That's how serious we take our love of magyckal lore!)

Check out all of the perk packages you can grab to the right and lower on the page, and keep checking back until the campaign ends. We’ll add at least a few more surprise perks as we think of them, and if you’ve got requests, we might even add a few of those too, so let us know in the comments.

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

SHOOT US AN EMAIL WITH ANY ALL QUESTIONS/REQUESTS AND WE WILL SEND YOU AN OWL BACK WITH OUR RESPONSE AS QUICKLY AS MAGYCKALLY POSSIBLE!

FAQ: About the Campaign

Why aren't you paying 100% for OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP yourselves?

Is a studio running this Indiegogo campaign with you?

 

FAQ: About OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP

When/Where will you shoot OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP? When will it come out?

What's OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP going to be about?

 

FAQ: About the Perks

What if the perk I want is sold out?

When will I get my perks?

Are all rewards available in all countries?

How will you know where to send my perks?

What if my address changes?

What happens if the movie never comes out?

What if I want more than one of the perks?

 

FAQ: About Specific Perks

How does the MOVIE TICKET perk work?

How do I get a MOVIE TICKET if I'm outside the USA? 

What if I get the MOVIE TICKET and there's no participating theater near me?

How will I get my DIGITAL DOWNLOAD perk?

What'll happen at the WINEFEST events?

If I get the PERSONALIZED VIDEO, what will you say in it?

How do PRIVATE SCREENINGS work?

If I NAME A CHARACTER, can I name it anything?

If I get the BE AN ACTOR perk, what will I say in the movie?

Will someone really get to keep THE WAND AND THE STAFF used in the movie?

 

Some people can't contribute (And Daddy Rink loves you all just the same!), but that doesn't mean you can't help!

GET IN ON THE ACTION AND HELP US SPREAD THE WORD!

 

1. Stalk us all over the internet. We’re  on Youtube, WeChat, WhatsApp and Kik, but you can also hang out with us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, Snapchat, Whosay, Meerkat, Jack'd, Blued, A4A, Grindr or whatever came out this morning. Get extra karma and LIKE whatever we post, and you’ll be helping your friends discover the greatest crowdfunding campaign they’ll ever join. Yes. It’s the greatest.

2. Annoy the ever loving shit out of your friends: we need to reach as many Sci-Fi/Fantasy The Cryptid Council novels fans and future fans as we can, and we can’t do it alone. Follow Us. Help us spread the word. Repost our stuff. Or post your own. We’ll share stuff that you post, and if you make your own cool stuff (like fan art, etc), let us know and we’ll share it as well.

3. Make everyone read a copy of OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP in magyckal anticipation: if your friends love the novels, throw a Hiklorik themed costume and elven dinner party. If you have friends who don’t love my books or the sci-fi/fantasy world, they’re clearly foreign spies who went to a charm school run by fools. Treat them as such!

OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP is a national treasure. Make your spy friend watch the movie until they love it. Then make them come to this page and give, even if it’s just $1.

4. Grab tickets for your friends now: You’re going to want to see this movie on opening night. Maybe you’ll go with all your friends. If you get your friends to get their tickets now, we’ll be able to make a better movie for you. So plan ahead, get your tickets, and help us shoot this thing properly.

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And like Porky Pig said before meeting the lettuce and tomato, a-ba-di-ba-di-a-ba-di-ba-di...

GET IN ON THE ACTION AND HELP US SPREAD THE WORD!
 
1. Stalk us all over the internet. We’re  on Youtube, WeChat, WhatsApp and Kik, but you can also hang out with us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, Snapchat, Whosay, Meerkat, Jack'd, Blued, A4A, Grindr or whatever came out this morning. Get extra karma and LIKE whatever we post, and you’ll be helping your friends discover the greatest crowdfunding campaign they’ll ever join. Yes. It’s the greatest.
2. Annoy the ever loving shit out of your friends: we need to reach as many Sci-Fi/Fantasy The Cryptid Council novels fans and future fans as we can, and we can’t do it alone. Follow Us. Help us spread the word. Repost our stuff. Or post your own. We’ll share stuff that you post, and if you make your own cool stuff (like fan art, etc), let us know and we’ll share it as well.
3. Make everyone read a copy of OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP in magyckal anticipation: if your friends love the novels, throw a Hiklorik themed costume and elven dinner party. If you have friends who don’t love my books or the sci-fi/fantasy world, they’re clearly foreign spies who went to a charm school run by fools. Treat them as such!
OF THE DARK AND THE DEEP is a national treasure. Make your spy friend watch the movie until they love it. Then make them come to this page and give, even if it’s just $1.
4. Grab tickets for your friends now: You’re going to want to see this movie on opening night. Maybe you’ll go with all your friends. If you get your friends to get their tickets now, we’ll be able to make a better movie for you. So plan ahead, get your tickets, and help us shoot this thing properly.
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
And like Porky Pig said before meeting the lettuce and tomato, a-ba-di-ba-di-a-ba-di-ba-di...

story:
Summary

S.L. Williams

Writer//Producer//Extraordinaire

Currently the Chief Executive Officer at SandChild Productions. 2018 Los Angeles Film School graduate earning a Bachelor’s of Science degree in film. United States Navy (FMF) sailor and OEF veteran. Background in anthropology, political science, linguistics, writing, and film production.

IAN is important to me for many reasons. First, it is the first project I have written AND produced. I believe in this project’s ability to launch future film ventures. Second, IAN is a vibrant story that has resonated with me since I read the Queerty article on which it is based, several years ago. It has sensitive and universal themes.

This endeavor also functions as the first entry for my film production company, SandChild Productions. Our singular objective is to create socially conscious content that focuses on diverse and remarkable characters, and innovative character dynamics.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re asking our donors to contribute $7,500 to our overall budget. Here’s how your donations will help:

  • Compensate cast & crew
  • Secure locations, permits, and insurance
  • Provide wardrobe & props
  • Compete in film festivals
  • Reach audiences with social media platforms and advertising.
  • Procure equipment, lodging, and transportation

We are excited to share our enthusiasm with our donors. Currently, our rewards include:

  • Social media shout outs
  • Digital downloads
  • Donor Credit
  • Friendship bracelets
  • “IAN” Crew T-shirts
  • Autographed script and promotional poster
  • Associate Producer credit
  • Wrap party invite

The Impact

IAN is a socially conscious film. We have a diverse cast and crew. And the story features themes of friendship and romance with an LGBT twist.

S.L. Williams has experience as a writer, producer, and script supervisor. Recent producer credits include short films:  Off The Clock, Cacophony, and, Dinner at Bailey’s. Recent writer credits include Embers (audio-drama), and Safe House.

Ralph Lucchese is an up and coming director with 3 Minute Man, Run, and, The Morning After. 3 Minute Man is receiving some acclaim for acceptance in the San Antonio Short Film Festival. Ralph also has experience as a 1st AD, sound design, and grip & electric.

Risks & Challenges

We’re all film school students and graduates, so we have some proficiency in development, pre-production, production, and post-production. As veterans and filmmakers, our most immediate obstacle is funding. But the success of this short film will be measured in its performance in film festivals.

We're relying on the emotional components of this story to resonate with audiences based on our experience as filmmakers and as people with similar experiences. We are also aware of the positive trends of similar projects. We’ll be using our collective experience to overcome challenges. We also each have capable mentors we may consult.

Other Ways You Can Help

Short films don’t get a lot of attention with the public. We’re asking those that can donate and those unable to donate to share our project. This story has universal themes that everyone can get behind. I’m very proud of what we’ve been able to accomplish thus far. If you could share with your acquaintances, friends, and family, we would be very appreciative. Please share our hashtags, #ianshortfilm and #elliotluvsian.

story:
Short Summary

This film is directed by Austin based filmmaker Sofia Martinez and will be the second installation of her films depicting mental health. Her latest work, Lady Lazarus focused on depression and she is excited to continue with a new and equally important topic: eating disorders.

How do the Donations Help?

The funds go directly into the production. We need help with locations, actors, sets, costumes and getting the word out. 

The Impact

Your contribution makes a ton of difference. Everyone who donates will be helping produce this very important and challenging film. Martinez Films has always gone through with their projects and are excited to make this one happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please share our page so more people can help! 

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story: N/A

Our Mission

This film was made through Sky Candle Films, a production company created by Penelope Kipps and Tristan Olson. As our first big project, 'Bailey.' starts the journey into creating fantastic and very real films. It has been a great learning curve for both of us, and while there may not be any more films released through Sky Candle, Penelope and Tristan both strive to continue to write and create films that will, hopefully, be as good as this one. 

The Story

'Bailey.' begins by introducing Bailey's life as a college student living with her best friend. They have a fun-filled life. Bailey was adopted and never knew much about her biological father until she receives a call from the adoption agency about a letter that was meant to be forwarded to Bailey. In this letter, Bailey learns that her father has been diagnosed with Huntington's Disease and she has a 50% chance of also having this disease. Hardened by the news that she might not live the full life she had planned, she makes an appointment to test to see if she has the disease and that leads to a long adventure of finding herself, coming to terms with her approaching death, and really figuring out who she is. 

The Film Festival Fee Fund

We already have a few film festivals lined up to submit to, but as we delve more into research, it becomes more apparent it's going to take a lot more than just submitting. Our film was zero-budget, made completely with Tristan and Penelope's savings. Now, we are faced with the ultimate task of submitting to festivals. We are asking your help so we can see our film spread around the world. 

All funds received will strictly be used for film festival submissions and nothing more. So, the more we raise, the further we can go!

The Perks of Backing

We want to thank you for backing and so we are giving you something back to anyone who donates. 

$5 - a personalised video thanks including a digital high five!

$10 - A private link to the film

$25 - A digital copy of the final script

$75 - We will mail you a print copy of the script signed by Tristan Olson and Penelope Kipps

$100 - You will be listed in the 'Special Thanks' in our films credits

$300 - You will be listed as 'Executive Producer' in our film

$500 - A chance to send Penelope Kipps a script 30 pages or less that she will produce and film for you! 

Everything helps, so even if you can only contribute $1, we will be forever grateful!

Thank you so much!

story:
AWOL follows the lives of Emma and Haydn, who are in crippling financial trouble. Like most Londoners, Emma works a menial job that she hates to make ends meet, while Haydn is lackadaisical towards finding employment. After Emma hitting breaking point, Haydn hatches a plan to fraudulently claim against his life insurance policy through faking his death. To do this successfully, they have to be cunning and make sure that they aren't caught in the process of committing fraud. Alongside this, they're having problems with their relationship. Will they make it through this rough patch together or will they get caught in the process?

 

 

Although the components behind making a film are expensive, the team has worked extensively to come up with innovative ways to make this film financially achievable. The estimated cost of this film is over £90,000! With access to equipment and our team being exceptional knowledgeable in their craft, we’re able to make huge savings on most of the film. However, some things, like locations and transport, still cost money. We just need a final £2,600 to produce AWOL to the highest possible standard. The pie chart below illustrates how the funds will be allocated.

 

We all have days where we’re at dinner with friends or family and hear about someone’s promotion, the new house someone has recently bought, or that rad holiday someone went on. If only there was something cool that you could share with those people. Something different that you know they haven’t done before. Maybe say that your name appears in a film. It would be really cool to see your name in a film, right? It’s something that allows our names to shine bright in the cinema screen, giving us bragging rights amongst our friends and family. How many people do you know are privileged enough to have their name immortalised in a film? By helping create AWOL, your name will have a special place in our credits. In addition, you will receive some really cool perks! Donating to this film could even make a really cool gift for a loved one, if you’re stuck on ideas.

Finally, you will be helping support a group of talented up and coming filmmakers to realise their collective dream of creating an exceptional short film to showcase their talents. 

 

There are unique challenges that will always pop up in production of a film. From changes in cast & crew to locations, production delays are an inevitable part of the independent filmmaking process.

If any setbacks do arise, we plan to keep you informed and give you reasonable dates of completion for the film. We so appreciate your trust in us as filmmakers; your money counts!

 


There are other ways that you can help us fund raise. Please share this Indiegogo with your family and friends. Also, you can follow us on social media:

https://www.facebook.com/FilmAWOL/

https://www.instagram.com/awolfilm/

Also, don't forget to use the hashtag #AWOLthefilm to keep up to date!

Thank you!

The AWOL Production Team

story:
About The Film

 

 

Synopsis: Adam has had a great run with his bestselling first novel. The boy wonder has been on every short list, won every notable award, and been feted all around town. It has even gone as far as thought leaders declaring him to be the next literary genius. Now his much-anticipated second novel is about to be released. When Adam reads a devastating review of the book by a highly respected critic, his shock is so great and deep that he is jolted into a parallel universe in which he co-exists with some of his characters from unfinished and discarded stories. While the characters vie against each other, they also challenge Adam to rise  to his role of creator, take the bull by the horns and make some tough decisions to get himself back on track with his destiny. One Hit Wonder is both a cautionary tale of not resting on one’s laurels and a motivational summoning of our deepest abilities to achieve our dreams.

Adam will be played by the mega talented Rizwan Manji (Paterson, Mr. Robot) with Casting by Brette Goldstein and photography by Nevil Jackson. The film will shoot in New York City. It is our intention to shoot in the Spring of 2018.

 

 

What We Need and What It Will Be Used For

We have already put in several months of careful preparations towards getting the film made. Now comes the stage for financing that will enable us to execute our carefully made prep. We can only do this with your generous help. We aim to raise in excess of 35K. The money we raise will be used for: location fees, camera and lighting equipment, crew salaries, casting and actors, wardrobe, sets and art direction. In post production (the portion after the shoot) we will need to fund editing, some visual effects, sound mix and color correction.

 

Tax Deductible

To give your kind contribution even more power, we are partnering with From The Heart Productions as a fiscal sponsor which will make it possible for all donations to be tax deductible to the extent of the law. The IRS allows deductions of the portion of your contribution which exceeds the fair market value of the goods or services you receive.

 

From the Heart has been successfully funding projects since its inception in 1993 under the 501(c)3 Internal Revenue Code of 1954.  They are also classified as a public charity under section 509(a)(2) of the Code.  As such, any monetary donations to their Fiscal Sponsorship Program qualify as charitable contributions under the U.S. Tax Code for 95 444 5418.

 

 

Key Cast and Crew

Rizwan Manji - The Star

 

Rizwan Manji is perhaps best known for playing Rajiv, the hysterically officious, scheming assistant manager of a call center in the NBC comedy Outsourced, part of the network’s prestigious Thursday night comedy lineup.

With a prolific career spanning nearly 20 years to date, some of Rizwan's memorable film credits include The Wolf of Wall Street, Charlie Wilson's War, The Dictator, Transformers, Don Jon, Equals and the critically acclaimed film Paterson.

Recently Rizwan wrapped The Man Who Killed Hitler and then The Bigfoot with Sam Elliot and Ron Livingston.

Rizwan has also appeared on many popular TV shows including Glee, Arrested Development, It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia, Without a Trace, NCIS and Bones.

Currently, Rizwan can be seen as Norm in USA's Mr. Robot. With partner, Dominique DiPierro (Grace Gummer) they are partnered up to investigate the "Five/Nine" hack. He can also be seen as the eternally optimistic real estate agent Ray Butani on the Pop TV sitcom Schitt's Creek, along with Eugene Levy and Catherine O'Hara. Rizwan also appears as royal advisor Tick Pickwick in SyFy’s The Magicians. 

 

Seyi River - The Writer and Director

 

New York filmmaker and  composer Seyi River (pronounced "shay") was a musician and performer at an early age. He studied acting at London's East 15 Acting School and music composition at Berklee College of Music in Boston.

Since his debut film Don’t Explain, he has directed and produced numerous shorts, music videos, commercials, and documentary films.

His award-winning documentary, If I Die Tonight, explores racial profiling from several perspectives. The controversial film is praised for its power, giving air to concerns of both the victims of police violence and of police officers and their families.

As a composer Seyi has written scores for his own films, as well as music for the films Love The Hard Way and Forty Shades Of Blue among others.

In recent years, Seyi entered the business and technology world as a founder in the audio space and has been active in enhancing audio products for filmed media.

 

Estelle Lee - The Co Producer

 

Actor, writer and producer Estelle Lee hails from Seoul where she studied law and worked briefly in finance. She took the leap to New York to pursue acting and is a recent graduate of the William Esper Studio. She has since enjoyed a variety of roles on stage and on screen including the role of Japanese emperor Hirohito in the immersive theater piece The Oracle and the anxious meditator Harmony in the film Lotus Unraveled.

Estelle is also an accomplished interpreter working with Korean filmmakers. Her clients include the New York Asian Film Festival, the Museum of Modern Art and most recently Netflix with whom she worked with on the premiere of the film Okja at the Cannes Film Festival.

As a writer Estelle recently wrote and produced Injustice League, a comedy sketch about a job interview gone horribly wrong when an Asian American woman applies for a superhero position. Currently she is working on developing a coffee themed web series.

 

Shan Shan Tam - The Co-Producer

Shan Shan is an independent television producer from Boston. She began her career in reality TV, then gravitated to long-form documentaries and food television, dipped her toe in documentary podcasts and live sports television, and is excited to work on her first film project. She is also a proud graduate of Wellesley College and a staunch advocate of the Oxford comma.

 

The Completed Film

After the film is completed we plan to bring it around and screen it at international film festivals. After a festival run we will get the film onto VOD (Video On Demand) platforms.

 

I Love Your Project! But I Can't Donate – What Else Can I Do?

We appreciate the love. We understand if you cannot donate. Please tell others in your immediate circle about our campaign. Perhaps publish the link to your social media channels and go to our website to sign up for our mailing list, and follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter so you can keep in touch with us throughout our journey. And send your good vibes our way. Thank you!

Perhaps publish the link to your social media channels and go to our website to sign up for our mailing list, and follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter so you can keep in touch with us throughout our journey. And send your good vibes our way. Thank you!

story:
Carry Tiger to Mountain is a dramatic short film about a compassionate Chinese caregiver who uses herbal medicine to treat a terminally ill patient, putting him at odds with the dying man's controlling daughter, who only believes in Western medicine.

Inspired by true events, Carry Tiger to Mountain deals with aging, a patient's right to choose, and the differences that can arise within a family regarding how one deals with a terminal illness; subjects that no doubt have affected, or will affect, everyone at some time in their lives.

By bringing this story out in the open, we hope to ignite a constructive and healthy dialogue about the lives and well-being of end-of-life caregivers and the people they care for. We hope our film will be used as a tool to promote healing among families and caregivers experiencing the illness of a loved one and the end of life decisions that accompany them.

We are seeking funding and support from individuals/organizations such as yourself to bring this important and universal story to life, which we intend to shoot in July. We need $10,000 in additional funding for production and post-production costs and any amount - from $25 to $3000 - would be greatly appreciated.

Please check out our great perks, from Mandarin lessons and script coverage to attending the premiere in Los Angeles.

We hope you will join us in bringing this universal story to life by contributing today to our IndieGoGo campaign.

Gratefully yours,

Rajiv, Jesse and Rob

P.S. Even you can't contribute funds, please help us out by using the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Thanks!

 

TEAM BIOS

RAJIV SHAH - Writer/Director

Rajiv Shah is an award-winning writer/filmmaker interested in telling stories that connect a broader audience to family dynamics and marginalized communities.

Rajiv’s first feature-length screenplay, Run the Tide, stars Taylor Lautner and Constance Zimmer. It was released theatrically by Orion Pictures and on DVD/VOD by Sony Pictures Home Entertainment. The screenplay for Run the Tide won the Grand Jury Prize for Project Catalyst at the Los Angeles Asian Pacific Film Festival, was a finalist in Final Draft's Big Break Competition, and placed in the top 10% of the Academy Nicholl Fellowship.

Rajiv won Showtime Networks' Tony Cox Screenwriting Award for Carry Tiger to Mountain (formerly titled The Yao of Tao) with Jesse Wang and Robert Berg in 2017. A web series he co-created with Aldo Pisano titled, Granny, premiered at the HBO New York Latino Film Festival that same year. He has co-written another feature screenplay about the early life of the Buddha titled The Failed Prince with Soham Mehta, and co-wrote the feature, 808, with Jared Asato which was selected as an Emerging Narrative fellow at the IFP Film Market in New York.

Rajiv is also proud to teach filmmaking to the next generation of storytellers with the Latino Film Institute's Youth Cinema Project, founded by Edward James Olmos. Rajiv's intention is to be in service to fostering creativity, literacy, and self-confidence through writing and filmmaking.

 

JESSE WANG - Writer/Role of TAO ZHANG

Jesse Wang hails from northeast China near the North Korean border. He came to the United States to pursue a medical research career and received a Ph.D. in Chemistry from Iowa State University. Jesse completed his postdoctoral fellowship in cell biology and neuroscience from Emory University. During his fellowship in Atlanta, Jesse was accidentally cast in a national commercial and caught the acting bug. Soon afterwards, Jesse started taking acting classes and started booking commercials and stage plays. Jesse moved to Los Angeles in 2004 to pursue acting full-time. 

His film credits include God's Not Dead, God's Not Dead 2, Two de Force, # 1 Serial Killer, and Dumpling, among many others. His television credits include Code Black, Twisted, Legends, Trophy Wife and Torchwood. Jesse won a best actor award for his portrayal of a shrewd business man in the short film Hard Money. He is the co-creator and star of the web series Mr. Wang Goes to Hollywood.

 

ROBERT BERG - Writer

Robert Berg has written and produced video and theater in the Los Angeles area for the past 28 years. He just completed a comedy feature screenplay based on Mr. Wang Goes to Hollywood, a YouTube comedy web series he co-created and co-wrote with Jesse Wang. He is currently producing a one-act comedy, Bad Sponsor,  for the 2018 Hollywood Fringe Festival. He has produced 3 short films that have recently appeared in festivals: Night of the Killer, Undercover and Hard Money.

RECOGNITION FOR FILMMAKERS

  • *WON - Showtime Networks Tony Cox Screenwriting Award. Nantucket Film Festival. Best Short Screenplay for THE YAO OF TAO.
  • *WON - Grand Jury Prize. Project Catalyst. Los Angeles. Asian Pacific Film Festival. Best Feature for RUN THE TIDE.
  • *NOMINATED - Best Dramatic Actor. FOX Teen Choice Award. Taylor Lautner for RUN THE TIDE.
  • *FINALIST - Final Draft Big Break Awards. Best Feature Screenplay for RUN THE TIDE.
  • *TOP 10% - Academy Nicholl Fellowship. Feature Screenplay for RUN THE TIDE.
  • *FELLOW - Independent Film Project (IFP). Emerging Narrative selection for the feature screenplay 808.
  • *WON - Audience Award. Connect Film Festival. Best Actor-Jesse Wang for HARD MONEY.
  • *WON - Golden Horse. Connect Film Festival. Best Comedy- Robert Berg for HARD MONEY.
  • *WON - Narrative Short Winner. International Independent Film Awards. Silver Award- Robert Berg for HARD MONEY.

story:
What We Are Doing

Screenwriter/actress Erin McShane drew from a deeply personal place to create this piece. Her mother passed away in 2014 from cancer. This film conveys the tragedy and the struggle of losing a parent and the powerful impact it has on family. 

The project features a veteran cast and crew: 

  • Mike Welch (James) - Twilight, Zombie Nation
  • Erin McShane (Emma) - Lucia Before and After, Wicked Attraction, Legend of Lonnie
  • Garret Schweighauser (Brian) - Severus Snape and the Marauders 
  • Richard Rennie (Kristoff) - principal dancer at the Moulin Rouge
  • Sophie Webb (Director) - Award nominated for best film at Canberra film festival

The Impact

Your donations will make it possible for a small dream to become a BIG reality. 

A story about relationships between people dealing with tragedy is something that affects us all, either directly, or indirectly when we see our friends coping with loss. 

Who is Attached to this Project

"My Mom is Dead" features a veteran cast and crew who are absolutely amazing. You've seen them everywhere.

Erin McShane -  She appeared in Sundance jury award winning film Lucia Before and After. You've also seen her in true crime documentary TV series Wicked Attraction, and Legend of Lonnie.

Michael Welch - Welch is best known for his role as the popular Mike Newton in the Twilight Film Series, a franchise that grossed $3.3 billion worldwide. More recently, he appeared as a series regular on Z Nation, Syfy's hit original zombie series. Michael was also a regular as Luke Girardi in the beloved, Emmy-nominated CBS show, Joan of Arcadia. His first feature film experience was as Artim in Star Trek: Insurrection, the ninth installment of the iconic franchise.
  Welch is passionate about the issue of clean water and is heavily involved with The Thirst Project, a youth oriented non-profit that builds fresh-water wells in developing communities.

Sophie Webb (Director) - Her short film based on the song Gimme All Your Love, by Alabama Shakes was personally selected by the band as a finalist in their online video contest. Most recently, Sophie created the original pilot Same Sex, which was selected for the 2017 IFP Screen Forward Labs in Brooklyn, New York. She is a passionate supporter of diversity and gender equality in the entertainment industry.

Angela Landis (Amber) - She's worked with directors like Christopher Columbus, John Wells, Peter Tolan and Daisy Mayer. Her acting credits include: Doubt, Jane the Virgin, Grey's Anatomy, Anger Management, ER, Bicentennial Man, and the Showtime Pilot The End of Steve. 

Erikka Innes (Producer) - She has independently produced three successful comedy albums (two were both audio and film), produced her own comedy tour, and appeared on shows like the Gong Show, Laughs on Fox, and Sirius XM's Hey Get Off My Lawn.

Richard Rennie (Kristoff) - Richard is known for his work on the comedy series @asst, Unverified and the upcoming feature film Bachelor Lions. Richard started his career as a Dancer and model at the age of 18. He worked for fashion brands including Yves Saint Lauren, Eleven Paris and DIM underwear. As a principle dancer he performed at the world famous cabaret 'Moulin Rouge' in Paris and worked for many artists including Duffy and Florence and the Machine. 

Other Ways You Can Help

SHARE! SHARE! SHARE!

   If you like our project, and can not donate, please share and get the word out to friends and family. I believe in this project and I know it will be a beautiful piece of film once it's finished. Thanks for believing in all of us and our dream.

story:
MILK KIDS is a 20 minute thriller short film that tells the story of three brave kids in th 1980s, who vow to escape the cult-like captivity of a sinister man and his doting wife.  

 

It's the 5 year anniversary of the abduction of our main character, 13 year old, Lux. Search efforts have restarted in a last ditch effort. Meanwhile, Lux is growing impatient. Her robes don't fit her anymore, and she's tired of her captor Malum's "higher learnings". After a traumatic incident, Lux declares that enough is enough. She won't be living out the "end of days" in this windowless basement. 

The emotional core of our story lands on literally and figuratively restoring the colour in the lives of these children. As they now all live a desaturated childhood in captivity, our main goal is to have a story of friendship and redemption. We also aim to discuss issues of ethics as we navigate through Malum's twisted perspective on the fate of humanity.  

With Milk Kid's inspiration being 1980s missing children milk carton campaigns, our hope is to capture the time period in all of its glory. Capturing the 80s aesthetic will involve vintage set pieces, costuming, hair styling, and an 80s inspired original score. 

 

WE LOVE THE '80s – from synth music to perms, to The Shining and Ferris Bueller's day off. Join us on this journey through 80's nostalgia. 

 

Milk Kids began pre-production in early February 2018. After working to create an extensive 200 page production plan as well as detailed story boards and an original script, it's just about time for us to head on set.

Your support for this campaign will help us keep on schedule for production in October, with a final edit to be completed by December. Once our film is complete, we hope to host the Canadian premiere of our film in Spring 2019. Stay tuned for updates and find out how to attend as a VIP in our perks! 

 

Milk Kids was developed by our group of 5 RTA Media Production students at Ryerson University as a part of our thesis film project. Our team is made up of many talented emerging filmmakers specializing in sound design & audio production, cinematography, editing, and more. All of us have come together to combine our production talents and passion for thriller films to create this ode to the 1980s. 

 

Leah Gugliotta

Director and Editor 

Hi there! I’m Leah from Messy Pictures and I am the director and editor of Milk Kids. I am an absolute movie buff and I cannot wait to make this 80s thriller short film come to life. My vision for Milk Kids is drawn from the thrill of Psycho mixed with the friendship from Stand By Me; my goal as director is to create something unique and different, with a splash of nostalgia. Join us on this exciting journey and remember: never cry over spilled milk.

 

Shuli Grosman-Gray 

Writer and Producer 

Shalom, everyone! I am the writer and producer of this culty tale. I was inspired to write a story about kids way in over their heads after watching the Netflix Original: End of The F***king World. I have high hopes for this twisted tale of friendship and sticking it to the man. 

 

 

 

Subash Sundaraling

Director of Photography

Hey! I'm Subash! I'm the Tech Lead and Director of Photography of Milk Kids. I'm a tech nerd who loves his gear. I love visual storytelling and creating cinematic shots using the best cameras and lights. I'm really excited to create something unique with the team and bring back the 80s vibe to our screens.

 

 

Alex Reinprecht 

Audio Lead 

I’m Alex, the Audio Lead! I am a huge nerd when it comes to sound (otherwise I’m really cool and not a nerd at all I swear. Please believe me) and have been playing and writing music for as long as I can remember. I want to help bring our film to life by taking us back in time through the Milk Kids score. 

 

 

Alessia De Luca 

Art Director 

Hello Hello! My name is Alessia and I am the Art Director and Assistant Editor for Milk Kids. I am extremely passionate about film, cinematography and music production. I look forward to visually recreating the nostalgic environment of the 80s that Milk Kids is set within!  

 

 

 

 

Your contributions to Milk Kids will go towards the costs of production, post-production, festival submissions, marketing and distribution costs necessary to successfully complete this project. 

Through Ryerson University, we are able to acquire most industry level equipment in order to keep our costs low, however we intend on using external rental houses for some camera and lighting equipment in order to achieve our desired finished product. Our second largest cost is set dressing. We intend on designing the most historically accurate set we can, by using costumes, signage and furnishings from vintage and thrift stores throughout the GTA.  

Making films is an inherently risky business, and we have taken great care in considering all possible obstacles in our production. With a creatively dedicated crew, consistent supervision by industry professionals, and an initial monetary contribution by our executive team, we have created a strong base to help kick this project off in October. 

 

 

Perks 

Every contribution over $10 grants you an automatic Thank You in the credits of the film. We recognize everyone who supports our project as an integral part of our film making process. All of our perks intend to offer you a creative reward including prints and merch with original artwork by Rayah Gugliotta of Paperback Studio.

While we are grateful for all financial contributions to this project, we understand that not everyone is in the position to donate. We also see the incredible value in social media posts and would love for your to share our Indiegogo page. 

 

Follow Us on Social Media 

By spreading the word on social media, you help increase our audience and the overall interest in our project. Follow our journey on set, and see where your investment is headed. 

We regularly post fun facts about thrilling 1980s missing person cases, vintage photography, and promotional material - so you always know what we're up to!  

 

  INSTAGRAM - https://www.instagram.com/milkkids.film/ 

 

 

 

  FACEBOOK –  https://www.facebook.com/milkkidsfilm/

 

 

 

We appreciate you joining us on this journey to create Milk Kids.

Sincerely, Messy Pictures.

story:
My name is Lucah Rosenberg Lee and about five years ago I partnered with J. Mitchel Reed to embark on creating a short documentary that changed our lives and countless others.

"Passing" for me, was my public coming out. In 2014, I was living and working as a trans man at a job where no one knew anything about my past. There were many times when a co-worker might make a derogatory comment about a trans person, not knowing they had been friends with someone trans for years. It was those types of experiences that made me want to open up about my gender transition.

At the time, my biggest fear was people knowing I was transgender. I thought if I came out, I'd never get a job again or I'd be discriminated against indefinitely. But I truly felt that this experience of going from a woman of colour to a man of colour, was a story deserving of being told, not only for myself but for the countless others who were and are going through the same thing.

Getting the subjects for "Passing" was a challenge because at the time, it was hard to find people willing to discuss their transition openly, but we found two incredible souls to participate, one in Texas and one in New York City. 

Amazingly, the day we started to shoot the film, Laverne Cox was on the cover of Time Magazine with the headline, "The Transgender Tipping Point:" it was then I knew we were moving in the right direction. Not only with this project, but within our entire culture.

Since the making of “Passing”, I’ve been touring the film and speaking to thousands of middle and high school kids discussing my almost 10-year experience with gender transition. Seeing the impact that our documentary short continues to have on all types of audiences and seeing the conversations it's still fostering and the questions that continue to be raised about gender, race, class and most recently, trans rights has propelled us to move to the next phase of this project -- a feature documentary.

It has been a truly incredible experience for us to see the ways lives have been touched by our content. One important element has been frequently asked questions about the cultural representation of trans people over the years. This has affected me on many levels as I reflect on what its been like growing up without any trans representation in the media. Not seeing trans people depicted in a positive light or for that matter, present at all, was in retrospect, quite impactful. Many people take for granted the positive impact of seeing people "like you" reflected in art and culture and its role in shaping feelings of acceptance as a competent, happy and valuable person. The truth is, I didn't even know what transgender was until I graduated high school.

And so we hope through creating a longer feature film, we can provide in a very open, accessible and public way, a vehicle to present meaningful stories that will engage a younger generation to feel safe discussing the multiple identities that might arise in their lives, and to understand that they can also change throughout time. At base, our new film follows our previous goals of representation and education in helping people form questions and figure out answers.

We made "Passing" in a time of cultural upturn and in many ways, we were apart of what turned out to be the beginning of a new level of understanding for ways we can move forward together. 

"Passing" the short was about going into the field, interviewing, and evaluating the trans experience in 2014.

"Passing: The Feature", will act to document what has changed, where we are in this moment when it comes to gender expression, identity, and politics of race, age and other constructions of difference. We ask: what sorts of challenges may lie ahead. Just as we did four years ago, we will follow the voices of our interviewees and the stories we uncover will shape our final film.

In the last few years, we have seen some incredible strides and some major setbacks. What does it mean to be transgender in 2018? How are trans folks navigating our current gender climate? Is the goal of passing in society as their chosen gender still something trans people seek or is visibility in our bodies actually becoming more important?

How can hearing the experiences of those who have lived as both male and female, deepen our societal understanding of how masculinity and feminity live inside all of us? 

Thank you for considering bringing this feature film to life, please feel free to watch "Passing" the short below!,

Thank you,

Lucah Rosenberg Lee

Watch "PASSING" FREE below;

 

 

What We Want To Do

We are hoping with this campaign to raise enough money to support the three major stages of making a feature documentary film. 

Making a feature film is a significant undertaking and with a documentary, there are often unexpected turns within each stage as the piece slowly comes together. This entire process will take around two years to fully complete and we aim to screen in 2020. The final product will be used in film festivals, universities and public school curriculums (just as "Passing" has been and continues to be) in an effort to educate varying communities for years to come.

Your investment in this piece goes further than many fictional narratives. Not only are we creating something that will be able to touch thousands of people and get them involved in important discussions, it will act to archive this extremely pivotal period we currently living in. 

Pre-Production

When we made our short film, "Passing," it was extremely difficult to find our subjects. We spoke to dozens of people and conducted pre-interviews and meetings over the course of about 6 months before getting Sasha and Victor to agree to be interviewed and filmed. Even though it might be a bit easier this time around (there are already multiple people we wanted in the first film but weren't able to fit who we'll be contacting) it will still take a considerable amount of time and effort. 

What we'll be paying for:

- Research

- Conducting pre-interviews

- Hiring our crew

- Production management

- Travel expenses

Production (filming, interviewing, traveling) 

The length of this period of the project will not be known until the first step is completed. 

What we'll be paying for:

- Camera package 

- Audio recordist

- Portable hard drives

- Room and board

Post-Production  (editing, colour and scoring) 

This process will last three to nine months. Sorting through every scrap and morsel of film captured leads to the molding of our story. The colour grading makes it watchable and the score holds it all together.

What we'll be paying for:

- Editing suite

- Colour grading at a Toronto post-production house like Alter Ego

- Sound mixing

- Musical Scoring

- RAID Harddrives for double back ups and the protection of where all the money goes: the footage.

Filmmakers

Lucah Rosenberg Lee

Lucah Rosenberg Lee is a Toronto based independent filmmaker who studied Sociology and Equity Studies at the University of Toronto. It was this education that sparked Lucah’s passion to pursue social issues in the form of documentary filmmaking.

Lucah was adopted from the Dominican Republic into a Toronto family who early on encouraged his love of filmmaking. His love for film and academics go hand in hand in his passion to tell stories that will move people. Lucah has spent the last few years traveling with "Passing" the short and speaking at high schools and universities across North America about his experiences being a trans man of color. He has completed 4 films and most recently helped produced Luis De Filippis's narrative Short, "For Nonna Anna", which screened at TIFF and Sundance, winning the Sundance Special Jury Prize 2018, as well as best short film at The Atalanta Film Festival. A film aimed to also forward the trans narrative.

​

J. Mitchel Reed

J. Mitchel Reed grew up in a home with two investigative journalists that fuelled his fire to hunt for stories and search for the truth. Surrounded by documentary films and news for his entire childhood and teenage years led him to pursue a degree in Ryerson’s RTA School of Media Program.

He graduated with honours and the President’s Award for his thesis feature film project. 

Mitch wants to continue to produce content that will challenge the status quo and encourage people to ask questions. 

 

Sharing and Donations 

Thank you so much for considering donating to the execution of this piece. If you cannot financially contribute, please feel free to share with anyone you feel may have the means to contribute to this movement. I can't wait to share this feature film upon completion.
story_txt:
My name is Lucah Rosenberg Lee and about five years ago I partnered with J. Mitchel Reed to embark on creating a short documentary that changed our lives and countless others.
"Passing" for me, was my public coming out. In 2014, I was living and working as a trans man at a job where no one knew anything about my past. There were many times when a co-worker might make a derogatory comment about a trans person, not knowing they had been friends with someone trans for years. It was those types of experiences that made me want to open up about my gender transition.
At the time, my biggest fear was people knowing I was transgender. I thought if I came out, I'd never get a job again or I'd be discriminated against indefinitely. But I truly felt that this experience of going from a woman of colour to a man of colour, was a story deserving of being told, not only for myself but for the countless others who were and are going through the same thing.
Getting the subjects for "Passing" was a challenge because at the time, it was hard to find people willing to discuss their transition openly, but we found two incredible souls to participate, one in Texas and one in New York City. 
Amazingly, the day we started to shoot the film, Laverne Cox was on the cover of Time Magazine with the headline, "The Transgender Tipping Point:" it was then I knew we were moving in the right direction. Not only with this project, but within our entire culture.

story:
Short Summary

Jenniffer Montenegro - Writer/Director

 

Film, TV and anything media related is my passion. Over the last few years, I have filled in different roles as a producer, writer and director in several projects including music videos, short films, and tv series, originally in Columbia, but now also in Australia.  Before coming to Australia, I worked as an executive producer on the Sesame Street children series and as a producer for the City Town Hall in Bogota.

Elsa is the true story of my family and how we experienced the grief of a loved-one. It is important to me to present the physical journey of Amanda and her father Pericles delivering Elsa's ashes to their final resting place with warmth, As I wish to show that even in extreme sadness, there can be hope and we can truly discover what real  love really means.

Lucas Salvatori - Cinematographer

 

I've always been attracted by the idea of visual communication and the power of emotional influence that film offers to the audience. I've also discovered that I'm happier while on set or working on anything related to that field. With 'Elsa', I aim to showcase the warmth that the Australian landscape brings to Elsa and Pericles' relationship, while honouring my Argentinian roots.

 

Camille Gaffney-Bowan - Producer

I have been a writer and Producer for the last few years in practice; but all of my life in hindsight. My passion is working as hard as I can to help put all the pieces together so that a film can run as smoothly as it can and realise its potential. With Elsa I will work even harder, as I believe that this story has a lot of heart and has the capability to touch a lot of people. After all - isn't that why stories are worth telling?

 

What We Need & What You Get

We aim to raise $8000. Most of the funds will be dedicated to Production Design, paying the talent, and housing and transporting the cast and crew during our 6-day shoot.

 

Should we not reach our goal, the raised funds will still be prioritised in this way. The overall visual feel, and the nature of transporting a 10-person crew will still be the highest costs with set design elements needed, cars, petrol and accommodation to house the crew during our proposed shoot from Sydney to Canberra and back.

 

The Impact

  • Even a small contribution to 'Elsa' will make an enormous difference to the finished edit of the film. Just $10 or one extra retweet may mean the difference between us being able to shoot for that extra hour to get that beautiful golden-hour sunset shot, or adding that extra bit of colour to the set design to fulfill the visual palette of the film.
  • We bring honesty, integrity and hard work to every project we work on and aim to be transparent in all of our happenings. We'll be easily accessible through Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to keep you up-to-date with how much your contributions will really help.

Risks & Challenges

Transporting, housing and feeding the cast and crew are the greatest risks. We are not only filming in static locations (such as interiors of houses) but outside on dirt roads, a creek, and country roads and towns between Canberra and Sydney. 

Though we did debate the difficulty of the logistics and potential risks (especially the weather as we will be filming during early July), we ultimately decided that the risk was worth it as the Australian inland landscape adds an extra quality to the film. Extra care will be taken to control for weather - hot water bottles, close by Unit bases and physical cover to shield from the elements

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • Any shout outs through sharing our social media pages with yours helps!
  • Just look above and feel free to re-tweet and/or share
