story:
I wrote this thing…

I wrote, am executive producing and acting in a short film titled I’m just here. It is a project that is very close to my heart for many reasons. My step sister recently came out to me as transgender and is currently transitioning and since then, something struck me as concerning. I realized that while there has been a push for more LGBTQIA characters in film and television, there are very rarely trans characters and the few times that there are, they are almost always stories of extreme tragedy. While I think it's important to honor the darkness that so many trans people have experienced, I also think it's important to show people stories of hope and inspiration. I hate the idea that on the rare occasion there is a trans character that my sister connects with, she is consistently shown a story almost exclusively of sadness. So I wrote a script. It respectfully acknowledges the struggles of a character who is trans but in the end is a story of encouragement and light. 

Another topic this story addresses is suicide prevention and mental health. The rate of suicide within the queer community is heartbreaking and within the trans community is even worse. A horrifying 41% of people who are trans have attempted suicide and we want to change that. The story of I’m just here tackles this topic head-on and sheds a light on it where many fear to go.

 

Some cool things about I’m just here

One thing that makes this project special is the talent that has been drawn to it. We have cast a top actor who has instrumental in LGBTQIA television history. Another thing that sets this project apart is that we have cast an actor who is actually transgender to play the role of the transgender character - an opportunity that is rarely taken in Hollywood and has received much criticism lately. We felt it was very important not to make that mistake and cast authentically. 

 

Another thing that makes us unique is that we are an almost entirely female crew - something that very rarely ever happens. It was important to all of us to give women opportunities to be involved because, sadly, they aren’t given as many as their male counterparts. 

 

#goals

Our goal is to make this short and get it into as many festivals as possible and spread awareness and education. We as filmmakers believe that our story has the ability to connect with a very diverse audience and has the potential to save lives. 

 

What we need from you

We need $10k (more is great, too!) in order to make this thing go. We will be using your generous donations to pay the incredibly talented people who have come aboard and agreed to lend their brilliant minds to the project. We will also be using the funding to apply to film festivals. By donating to our film, you will literally get to see your kindness spread awareness, touch peoples hearts, and potentially save lives. 

 

For our international friends

We know that some countries aren't able to donate through indiegogo, so we welcome any donations you'd like to make via paypal! Our paypal email address is: imjustherefilm@gmail.com. Don't hesitate to shoot us an email if you're having trouble or would like a confirmation that your donation went through. Thanks so much!

story:
alla versione in italiano

zur deutschen Version

 

What you should now about the project, the money and the schedule

The project, the Collas and me: I'm a writer, creator and filmmaker. More than 20 years ago I started making films and videos.
This is the first crowdfunding ever I start. Asking people to give money for my own personal effort is not something I take lightly.  
I raise money to make a documentary about the fascinating Milan Compagnia Marionettisti Carlo Colla & figli which I met the first time four years ago when my team and I prepared for a recording of the baroque opera "Rinaldo" performed by "the Collas" for an Arthaus-DVD.

We met fascinating people who are modest and stand almost shy behind their craft and thus enchant their audience with true passion. My fascination grew when I spent a summer day in their Milan atelier and shot some pictures (which you can see in the trailer). I watched them building, repairing, tailoring, carving, painting ... As my fascination about the Collas grew, so did my will to make a full-length documentary about them. I want wo produce a film that is entirely dedicated to its subject, which avoids the doubts of TV editors about expected audience ratios as well as profitability calculations of production companies. A film that is financed by people who are as interested as I am in the Compagnia Carlo Colla & figli. The Collas are an impressive living, contemporary monument to craftsmanship that assert themselves in an increasingly digitally networked world with their analogue art, which focuses on the moment of the experience of a theatre performance.

 

 

Let me take you by the hand to accompany the Collas, in the year. You will have a look backstage, so you will see how they develop a production from the very beginning to the premiere. You will get to know people, their lives, their passions, their motivations. How they found their way to the tradition of puppet theatre, which relationships they have with their wooden protégés. Together we will get to know a group of artists who live with their craft between tradition and transition. And we will learn that the Collas follow a long line of tradition that began 200 years ago. They have been pop stars and they had breaks: fame and sadness, success and defeats all that in one history. They were a national monument of arts in northern Italy.
We will talk to the puppeteers and to people who have accompanied, supported and encouraged them, people who worked with them. We are going to go on tour with them to the Spoleto festival dei due mondi in Charleston/SC and to New York in November where they will perform a week at a theatre near the Broadway.

We will also accompany the Collas when they move their atelier to a new location, when they prepare the grand opening of their museum in Milan/Italy.


Look and feel: I imagine a quiet, sensitive documentary film that accompanies the collas and lets the protagonists show us their world. A film that takes time to watch. A film that gives its protagonists enough space to tell the audience their story. 

The money: Asking people to give money for my own personal effort is not something I take lightly. But I'm convinced that the own personal effort turns into something to share: I am sure that I can give a lot back: a documentary film with an interesting subject, an insight into a wonderful world of puppet theatre, a glimpse at a time that only seemed to be long gone – but the Collas keep alive. So we calculated the fundamental costs it will take to make the planned documentary. Most of the money (about 70%) is needed for the filming, the lighting and camera, team and equipment. Technically we don't skimp on image and sound quality: as little as possible, as much as necessary for the best result. We hope we can manage the postproduction with about 15%; organization, insurance, unexpected issues and so on: about 5% and finally 10% for transportation to the locations in Italy, Germany and the USA.


Every donation counts. If you are unable to support the project financially, sharing will also help.
In addition to what you can contribute, you can support our search by publishing the campaign on all kinds of social media and encouraging your friends and co-workers to contribute as well.

I really can't overestimate what your participation means to me.

 

The perks: First of all you can expect a touching full-length documentary film about the humans and the marionettes of the Compagnia Carlo Colla & figli, their art and their craftsmanship, their passion for puppet theatre.
We make an effort to make you participate as closely as possible in the project. For that we have above the $50 level an area on the project's website with schooting schedule, photographs, rough cuts and a production log.
Should we exceed our financial goal, we will use the money to ensure an even higher quality  or/and increase the visibility of the film on the festival circuit with additional submissions and more representation at festivals.
Should we fail to achieve our financial goal so it will take a longer time to make the documentary. Maybe we travel less. But we will tell the story of the Collas and we'll make this film. Because I'm obstinate and never give up easily so we will bring the project to a happy end.

 

Versione italiana

Cosa si dovrebbe sapere sul progetto, i soldi e il calendario

Ricordo molto bene il momento in cui ho incontrato per la prima volta “i Colla”: è stato un giorno di febbraio a Karlsruhe. Eravamo occupati a registrare l’opera di Händel “Rinaldo” per Arthaus-DVD, eseguita dalla Lautten Company Berlin e con le marionette della Compagnia Carlo Colla & figli di Milano. Ho capito subito che persone in tutto il mondo devono innamorarsi del mondo magico creato e trasmesso dai marionettisti quando assistono ad uno spettacolo dei Colla. Loro riescono ad entusiasmare il pubblico con le loro marionette di legno di un’altezza di appena un metro e trasportarlo in un mondo di favole. Alla conclusione di una serata al teatro con i Colla bisogna stropicciarsi gli occhi come se ci si svegliasse da un sogno bellissimo.

Chi ha avuto a che fare con i Colla può, raccontandone la storia, contribuire a fare crescere la fama misteriosa del gruppo, con il loro atelier ed il loro magazzino in un cortile di una chiesa che si trova in un paesino alle porte di Milano, dove conservano migliaia e migliaia di accessori di scena, le quinte, marionette, parrucche e costumi. Con alle spalle una storia di 200 anni, che ne ha fatto un monumento nazionale, perché la loro arte era talmente apprezzata da eseguire persino opere e balletti del Teatro della Scala, e che famosi e conosciuti artisti di teatro parlano con entusiasmo della collaborazione con i Colla….

Un giorno decisi di andare a Milano di persona e ho scoperto che tutte queste storie sono vere. Ho avuto modo di passare una bellissima giornata in un luogo magico, in un regno di innumerevoli marionette, un luogo pieno di storia. I membri del gruppo erano impegnati a fare lavori da falegname, a dipingere, ad acconciare, a cucire, a riparare. Si percepiva un’area di concentrazione, avvolta dal suono di una vecchia radio che suonava tipiche melodie italiane intonate da degli altoparlanti.

Più sentivo il fascino che trasmettevano i Colla su di me, più cresceva il mio desiderio di girare un documentario su questo gruppo teatrale. Un film dedicato totalmente al loro soggetto, che è lontano dalle preoccupazioni delle redazioni TV a riguardo degli indici di ascolto, e lontano dai calcoli di redditività dalle case di produzione. Un film finanziato tramite "crowdfunding", da persone come me, interessate alla storia e all’arte della Carlo Colla & figli.

I Colla sono un monumento vivo e presente ad un mestiere che si afferma nell’ambito analogico dell’arte teatrale, che cattura il momento dello spettacolo teatrale e che va contro un mondo virtuale e digitale.

Con questo film voglio prendervi per mano e guardare dietro le quinte dei Colla, guardare la loro vita, la loro storia, il loro mestiere e naturalmente voglio guardare la loro arte, comprendere la loro passione per il teatro delle marionette. Seguiremo la nascita di una nuova messa in scena dagli inizi fino alla prima, parleremo con uomini che hanno affiancato e assistito i Colla. Incontreremo anche delle persone ispirate ai Colla e probabilmente seguiremo i Colla nella loro tournée’, al Festival di Spoleto dei due mondi, a Charleston in Sud Carolina e possibilmente anche a New York dove i marionettisti milanesi saranno ospiti di un teatro vicino a Broadway.

Accompagneremo i Colla quando traslocheranno con il loro atelier e quando apriranno un loro museo in una località rinomata di Milano.

 

Sto pensando ad un film tranquillo, sensibile e discreto. Un film che si prende tutto il tempo necessario. Un film, che accompagna i Colla quando aprono il loro mondo agli spettatori. Un film che dia lo spazio ai suoi protagonisti di raccontare la loro storia al pubblico.

Questa è la mia primissima campagna di crowdfunding. Dovete credermi quando vi dico che non mi riesce facile chiedere ad altre persone dei soldi per il mio progetto, ma sono convinto che, l’anno prossimo, con il mio film compiuto, potrò restituire tanto ai donatori.

Se questa campagna supera l' obiettivo di finanziamento, le entrate supplementari saranno investite nel film al 100%.

In una campagna aperta, si pone sempre la domanda: cosa succede se l' obiettivo di finanziamento non viene raggiunto? Poi il lavoro sul film potrebbe richiedere un po' più tempo, e poi potremmo viaggiare meno. Ma una cosa è certa: questo film sarà realizzato. Se sono convinto di un progetto come me del film sui Colla, non mi arrendo mai (quasi) mai.

 

 

 

Die deutsche Version

Was Sie über das Projekt, das Geld und den Zeitplan wissen sollten

Jeder, der schon einmal mit den Collas zu tun hatte, kennt solche Details: dass sie in einem versteckten Kirchhof in einem Mailänder Vorort ihr Atelier und ihr Depot betreiben, dass sie dort Tausende und Abertausende Requisiten, Kulissenteile, Marionetten, Perücken und Kostüme aufbewahren. Dass ihre Geschichte schon mindestens 200 Jahre verläuft, dass sie einst Nationaldenkmal waren, weil ihre Theaterkunst so beliebt war, dass sie Opern und Ballette des berühmten Opernhauses Teatro alla Scala nachspielten, dass berühmte italienische Theaterleute von der Zusammenarbeit mit ihnen schwärmen ...

 

 

Je stärker meine Faszination über die Collas wuchs, desto stärker wuchs auch mein Entschluss, eine Dokumentation über diese Theatertruppe zu drehen. Einen Film zu produzieren, der sich ganz seinem Sujet widmet, der die pessimistischen Bedenken von TV-Redaktionen über zu erwartende Einschaltquoten genau so vermeidet wie Rentabilitätsrechnungen von Produktionsfirmen. Ein Film, der via Crowdfunding von Menschen finanziert wird, die sich genau so wie wir für die Compagnia Carlo Colla & figli, ihre Geschichte und ihre Kunst interessiert, wie wir das tun. Die Collas sind ein beeindruckendes lebendes, ganz gegenwärtiges Denkmal eines Handwerks, die sich in einer zunehmend digital vernetzten Welt mit ihrer analogen, auf den Moment des Erlebnisses einer Theateraufführung konzentrierenden Kunst behaupten.

Mit diesem Film möchte ich Sie gerne bei der Hand nehmen und mit Ihnen einen tiefen Blick hinter die Kulissen der Collas werfen, ihr Leben, ihre Geschichte, ihr Handwerk und selbstverständlich ihre Kunst ansehen, ihre Leidenschaft für Marionettentheater verstehen. Wir werden die Entstehung einer neuen Inszenierung („Ein Sommernachtstraum") vom Anfang bis zur Premiere mitverfolgen, werden mit Menschen sprechen, die die Collas begleitet und unterstützt haben, werden auch Menschen treffen, die von den Collas inspiriert wurden, werden wahrscheinlich mit den Collas auf Tour gehen, zum Spoleto Festival dei due mondi in Charleston, South Carolina, und möglicherweise auch nach New York, wo die Mailänder Puppenspieler in einem Theater nahe des Broadway gastieren werden. Wir werden die Collas dabei begleiten, wenn sie mit ihrem Atelier an einen neuen Ort umziehen und wenn sie ihr Museum an einer der angesagtesten Locations in Mailand eröffnen werden.

Ich stelle mir einen ruhigen, sensiblen, zurückhaltenden Film vor. Einen Film, der sich Zeit nimmt. Einen Film, der die Collas begleitet, in dem sie den Zuschauern ihre Welt öffnen. Einen Film, der seinen Protagonisten genügend Raum gibt, dem Publikum ihre Geschichte zu erzählen.

Es ist die erste Crowdfunding Kampagne, die ich starte. Und, glauben Sie mir, es fällt mir gewiss nicht leicht, andere Menschen um Geld für ein eigenes Projekt zu bitten. Aber ich bin überzeugt, dass ich mit dem fertigen Film im kommenden Jahr den Spendern vieles zurückgeben werde.

Sollte diese Kampagne das Finanzierungsziel übertreffen, werden die Mehrerlöse in den Film fließen: dann kann das eine oder andere Equipment mehr angemietet, der eine oder andere Drehtag mehr gebucht werden

Bei einer offenen Kampagne stellt sich auch immer die Frage: was passiert, wenn das Finanzierungsziel NICHT erreicht wird? Nun, dann wird die Arbeit an dem Film möglicherweise etwas länger dauern, dann werden möglicherweise weniger Reisen gemacht werden. Aber eines ist sicher: dieser Film wird entstehen. Wenn ich von einem Projekt so überzeugt bin wie von dem Film über die Collas, dann gebe ich (fast) nie auf.

Bitte unterstützen Sie das Projekt mit einem Beitrag.
story_txt: alla versione in italianozur deutschen Version  What you should now about the project, the money and the scheduleThe project, the Collas and me: I'm a writer, creator and filmmaker. More than 20 years ago I started making films and videos.This is the first crowdfunding ever I start. Asking people to give money for my own personal effort is not something I take lightly.  I raise money to make a documentary about the fascinating Milan Compagnia Marionettisti Carlo Colla & figli which I met the first time four years ago when my team and I prepared for a recording of the baroque opera "Rinaldo" performed by "the Collas" for an Arthaus-DVD.We met fascinating people who are modest and stand almost shy behind their craft and thus enchant their audience with true passion. My fascination grew when I spent a summer day in their Milan atelier and shot some pictures (which you can see in the trailer). I watched them building, repairing, tailoring, carving, painting ... As my fascination about the Collas grew, so did my will to make a full-length documentary about them. I want wo produce a film that is entirely dedicated to its subject, which avoids the doubts of TV editors about expected audience ratios as well as profitability calculations of production companies. A film that is financed by people who are as interested as I am in the Compagnia Carlo Colla & figli. The Collas are an impressive living, contemporary monument to craftsmanship that assert themselves in an increasingly digitally networked world with their analogue art, which focuses on the moment of the experience of a theatre performance.  Let me take you by the hand to accompany the Collas, in the year. You will have a look backstage, so you will see how they develop a production from the very beginning to the premiere. You will get to know people, their lives, their passions, their motivations. How they found their way to the tradition of puppet theatre, which relationships they have with their wooden protégés. Together we will get to know a group of artists who live with their craft between tradition and transition. And we will learn that the Collas follow a long line of tradition that began 200 years ago. They have been pop stars and they had breaks: fame and sadness, success and defeats all that in one history. They were a national monument of arts in northern Italy.We will talk to the puppeteers and to people who have accompanied, supported and encouraged them, people who worked with them. We are going to go on tour with them to the Spoleto festival dei due mondi in Charleston/SC and to New York in November where they will perform a week at a theatre near the Broadway.We will also accompany the Collas when they move their atelier to a new location, when they prepare the grand opening of their museum in Milan/Italy.Look and feel: I imagine a quiet, sensitive documentary film that accompanies the collas and lets the protagonists show us their world. A film that takes time to watch. A film that gives its protagonists enough space to tell the audience their story. The money: Asking people to give money for my own personal effort is not something I take lightly. But I'm convinced that the own personal effort turns into something to share: I am sure that I can give a lot back: a documentary film with an interesting subject, an insight into a wonderful world of puppet theatre, a glimpse at a time that only seemed to be long gone – but the Collas keep alive. So we calculated the fundamental costs it will take to make the planned documentary. Most of the money (about 70%) is needed for the filming, the lighting and camera, team and equipment. Technically we don't skimp on image and sound quality: as little as possible, as much as necessary for the best result. We hope we can manage the postproduction with about 15%; organization, insurance, unexpected issues and so on: about 5% and finally 10% for transportation to the locations in Italy, Germany and the USA.Every donation counts. If you are unable to support the project financially, sharing will also help.In addition to what you can contribute, you can support our search by publishing the campaign on all kinds of social media and encouraging your friends and co-workers to contribute as well.I really can't overestimate what your participation means to me. The perks: First of all you can expect a touching full-length documentary film about the humans and the marionettes of the Compagnia Carlo Colla & figli, their art and their craftsmanship, their passion for puppet theatre.We make an effort to make you participate as closely as possible in the project. For that we have above the $50 level an area on the project's website with schooting schedule, photographs, rough cuts and a production log.Should we exceed our financial goal, we will use the money to ensure an even higher quality  or/and increase the visibility of the film on the festival circuit with additional submissions and more representation at festivals.Should we fail to achieve our financial goal so it will take a longer time to make the documentary. Maybe we travel less. But we will tell the story of the Collas and we'll make this film. Because I'm obstinate and never give up easily so we will bring the project to a happy end.  Versione italiana Cosa si dovrebbe sapere sul progetto, i soldi e il calendarioRicordo molto bene il momento in cui ho incontrato per la prima volta “i Colla”: è stato un giorno di febbraio a Karlsruhe. story:
Thanks for taking time to visit my campaign to make my documentary BackBurner Dreams a reality and bring it to the public.

Although BackBurner Dreams focuses on three women, I believe their stories are shared by many women, including me. For most of my life I've lived up to the expectations of parents, a spouse, society, all the while ignoring the desires, passions and dreams I had for my life.  At age 58 I amplified the voice I silenced for so many years and took the steps necessary to get to this point in my life as director/producer of my first film.

Your contribution will help pay for the post-production costs associated with completing a film - editing, cinematography, original score, color correction, venue fees, marketing. No amount is too small or too great.

I hope BackBurner Dreams sparks proactive dialogue and inspires viewers to remember and honor the dreams they hold dear.

What I Need & What You Get

          I hope to raise $3,280 to cover post-production costs as well as a final day of filming

           $450 - cinematography

$400 - original score

$1,500 - initial screenings venue fees

$400 - color correction

$50 - posters

$50 - postcards

$30 - business cards

$400  - editing

.

Any amount is appreciated but a $50 donation will get you a shout out in the closing credits and for $100 you will receive 2 complimentary V.I.P. tickets for a screening in your city.

If the goal isn't reached, I will use the funds as efficaciously as possible to have the most impact and deliver a beautiful film.

The Impact

I've met so many women during the production of BackBurner Dreams who seemingly were waiting for someone to ask them, "What's your back burner dream"? I think we're at a time in our history where women are realizing their power, impact and ability to make change. I think the begining of social change begins with individual change. Imagine a community, a world, where women could live and be their whole selves, including realizing their deepest dreams and desires. I hope BackBurner Dreams inspires many personal moments of realization and revelation. 

While BackBurner Dreams is the first film I've directed and produced, I co-produced Vow of Silence at film short by Be Steadwell which has screened both nationally and internationally including  Schomburg Center For Research In Black Culture. I also helped produce some of Be Steadwell's music videos.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute financially, spreading the word about my campaign is invaluable, please share the link and thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Drew Seich and I am the Director and Co-Writer for the film Brain Juice

  • This film is a labor of love for zombie film cinema and dark comedies.
  • By donating you will be helping the film get to screens everywhere! And hopefully in your DVD Collection!

 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need is help with costs of making such a film. We need money for costuming, set design, food for the cast and crew, gas money, etc, etc.

  • For this film to become a reality we need you help with funding, if we are to make this film a reality.
  • So as way of thanks for helping the creation of this film we have several awesome perks from you to pick from that could get you a DVD of the film, a Poster, or even you name in the credits

Risks & Challenges

As we know this amount of money need is no small feat to reach and no small fee in general. We the cast and crew are very excited to get this film into production and bring this film to life. But without your help this will not happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute there are still ways to help!

  • Tell people about the film!
  • Share posts about the film on your social media sites!

Tell people about the film!
Share posts about the film on your social media sites!

story:
Director's Statement 

For years, every night, before I went to sleep, I would pray to God that my mother wouldn’t die. Jews don’t kneel when we pray, or at least I was never taught to, so in the dark I would lie on my back and look at the glow-in-the-dark stars on the ceiling and mutter a hymn memorized rote from years of Hebrew School on early Sunday mornings. She was always in constant peril, always at the mercy of some imaginary car accident or mass shooting or heart attack.

 

The film is an unapologetic flourish of pageantry, but it is also a repository of my anxieties -- the fear of my losing my mother, the fear of the modern world with its thousand opportunities for oblivion at every turn -- and my desire to find relief in all the fantasy of art and song and poetry.

Why we need your help

We shot the film in December with a diverse crew of artists, musicians, dancers, and filmmakers -- but we still need funds for post production. Your contribution will go towards paying our editor, sound mixer, and colorist.  With your donation you are declaring your support of emerging queer cinema, new voices in musical theater, and helping us get the momentum to turn this short into a feature-length project.


 

Who we are

 

CREW

Max Rifkind-Barron - Writer/ Director

Max is an NYC-based writer, director, and producer. An MFA screenwriting candidate at Columbia, he wrote and produced the short ﬁlm Pipe Dream, which screened at over 20 ﬁlm festivals, including Frameline and Outfest. Pipe Dream was acquired by Warner Brothers Television and is currently in development as a web series. He produced Madeleine Olnek’s Wild Nights with Emily, a feature-length comedy starring Molly Shannon as the poet Emily Dickinson, which will have its world premiere this March at SXSW. He serves on the board of Film Forum, one of New York’s leading art house cinemas. 

Alex Peace - Producer 

Alex is a ﬁlmmaker originally from Manchester, England. She is a graduate of the Columbia MFA Directing program. She has worked as a Producer and Production Manager on features, commercials and other platforms. Most recently, she Line Produced Madeleine Olnek's Wild Nights with Emily starring Molly Shannon, Amy Seimetz, and Brett Gelman which will premiere at the 2018 SXSW festival. 

Teddy Poll - Composer 

As a composer, Teddy has won an ASCAP Morton Gould Young Composer Award and two Singing City prizes. His ﬁrst opera, based on Lorca’s play Yerma, was premiered in New York at the NOMADS Festival. His second opera, in process, is set to religious texts by Auden and Yeats. He was a summer fellow at the European American Musical Alliance in Paris from 2006 to 2008, and studied composition with Samuel Adler at the Freie Universität in Berlin in 2010 and 2011. He has been commissioned by the Philadelphia Chamber Music Society and the Presser Foundation to compose a string quartet in honor of Robert Capanna for performance in the 2017–18 season.

Arseni Khachaturan - Director of Photography 

Arseni’s portfolio includes ﬁction feature ﬁlms, shorts and documentaries alongside commercials, music videos and branded content. His work has been screened at Cannes International ﬁlm festival, Berlinale, Tribeca, Rotterdam, Locarno and MoMA museum of modern art.

Sammi Sadicario - Associate Producer/ Social Media Manager 

Sammi Sadicario is an actress and singer, making her film-producing debut as AP.  She earned her BFA from Penn State Musical Theatre with a minor in Religious Studies.  This enabled her to write, produce and perform her one-woman show titled Part Time Believer, exploring the relationship between performance and ritual.  Regional credits include: Rock of Ages (Millbrook Playhouse), The Little Mermaid (Millbrook Playhouse),  The Lightning Thief, (National Tour) Off-Broadway: All Aboard! The Musical.  Sammi jumped into film in 2017, and continues to follow her passion of creating art through accessible mediums. 

Rosa Callejas - Production Designer

Rosa is a NY based Production Designer. She holds a Master in Architecture and a BFA in Visual Arts from the European University of Madrid. She worked as an Architect for 7 years, exploring since then how to create and interact with space and materials from multiple types of arts. When she moved to NY, she got hooked on film and discovered her passion designing the universe that surrounds innumerable stories to be told. She has work for directors like Julia Solomonoff, Dan Powell and Jim McKay; companies incl. Starbucks, Amazon and Google; and stars as Christina Ricci, Amy Sedaris, Chris Elliot and Franchesca Ramsey.

Nicole Rauscher - Costume Designer 

Nicole Rauscher is a costume designer, set costumer and wardrobe supervisor based in New York. A member of Locals 829 and 764 Rauscher has a wide range of design and production experience in independent film, theater and dance gained in the US and in Europe. Born in the Black Forest, Germany to a skilled seamstress and master pastry chef, she trained in theater arts and contemporary dance in Holland and Germany. Her creativity and craftsmanship were honed through her work  under esteemed textile designer, Doris Tillett. In 2006 Rauscher co-founded the boutique design firm Tillett & Rauscher Inc. whose endeavors blend the disciplines of textile making, interior design, specialized lighting and theater arts. In 2011 four of T&R’s fabric designs were taken into the permanent collection of the Smithsonian/Cooper Hewitt Design Museum. Recent costume design credits include the opera ‘Cassandre’ at the Athenée theater in Paris, ‘King Lear’ at the Comédie de Genève in Switzerland, and assistant costume designer on the independent feature ‘Monsters and Men’.

Christopher Trepinski- Choreographer

Christopher Trepinski (Choreographer) is a musical theatre actor, singer, dancer and choreographer from Lawrence, KS and calls NYC home.  He has performed nationally and internationally in projects ranging from opera and musical theatre to concert dance in venues sprawling from regional theatre to Off-Broadway stages and the high seas to Carnegie Hall.  He is a proud member of AEA.  Please consider a donation to Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

CAST

 

Max Bartos - Grand Duchess Menorah/ Micah

Max William Bartos - Max Bartos is from Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and spends a lot of time in New York City.  Max is a born performer, having sung, danced, directed and acted since he could speak.  He has also enjoyed a variety of sports, and was a four-season lacrosse player until a concussion ended his playing days.  He continued to take voice lessons in Lancaster, and soon was auditioning for Prather Entertainment, landing the role of Scut Farcus in its production of A Christmas Story The Musical at the Dutch Apple Dinner Theater, starting him down the path of his professional career.  

He has had the privilege of working with a variety of musical theater, TV, and film professionals and has been in several films, including The Lottery and Forget-Me-Not.  Max plays guitar and in his spare time has started to write and compose his own songs.  Max is currently studying with Drew Gasparini and Joanne Abrom for voice, Walker Clark for acting and Dance Molinari, Creative Pursuits Studio and Popovsky Performing Arts for dance. Max is a proud member of Actors Equity Association and SAG-AFTRA.  This past spring, he originated the role of Josh in the 29 and 60-hour staged readings for a new musical Other World, written by Hunter Bell, Jeff Bowen and Ann McNamee.  He recently played the role of Billy Kopecki in Big: The Musical at the Fulton Theater in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.  Max is currently working on an AEA staged reading for a new play in New York City.

David Winning - Robert 

David Winning is an actor with a broad range of acting credits, including TV, film, and stage, over the past 15 years. When not auditioning or on set, he can often be found at the local hardware store picking up tools and supplies for a variety of handyman projects in and around his house. David enjoys working out at the gym, riding his motorcycle, and spending time with his wife and two daughters.

Lisa Haas - The General Manager 

Lisa Haas is a comedy writer and actor. In addition to appearing in “Codependent Lesbian Space Alien Seeks Same” she was a co-screen writer and co-star in Madeleine Olnek’s 2014 feature “The Foxy Merkins”. She has performed on stage in many NYC and she is currently working on a new comedy, “Un-Bad” which she’s hopes to premiere in 2018. 

Malin Barr - Magician Queer 

Malin Barr is a Swedish actress, singer, dancer trained at Laine Theatre Arts, UK, towards a National Diploma. Shemoved to NYC in 2012 and have since then worked in bothMusical Theatre, Dance and Film/TV.                                                                                               

Malin have performed in various productions including ´Chicago’ (Hunyak), ´Legend of Yauna’ (BAM, Choreo.Maija Garcia), ´The Resolute’ (WYO Theatre Festival) , Araberlin (NYTW/Horizon Rep.), The Shakespeare Project (Theatre 4 the people/Isaac Byrne)

TV/Film credits include Co-Stars on shows as Bull (CBS), My crazy Love (Oxygen Networks and feature films First Love, Beachhouse and short films; Hedda Needs Help, Two Fish, Bedbugs& Co (Berlin FF, CannesFF , Hollywood Comedy Shorts etc ).

Resa Mishina - Heim the Human Domino 

Resa Mishina is a recent graduate from Rider University, earning a BFA in musical theatre. She was a competitive gymnast for 10 years before pursuing her passion in theatre. Originally from Japan, Resa represented the city of Tokyo at the 2016 Olympic Games bid in Copenhagen as a future Olympian. She has performed regionally at Flat Rock Playhouse in You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown (Woodstock), Annie (Duffy), Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, 9 to 5, and The Music Man, as well as TEXAS at Texas Musical Drama and Miss Saigon at Interlakes Summer Theatre.

Danielle Strauss - The Erotic Puppeteer 

Danielle Strauss can be seen as Jessica in the upcoming feature film How To Get Girls with Chris Elliott, David Koechner, and Chris Kattan. Other films include Public Affairs with Thora Birch and Adrian Grenier, Black Box (ITVFest, Zero Film Festival), and Lucia Before and After (Sundance). Theater: How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Madison Square Garden and National Tour), Off-Broadway: Unbroken Circle, The Awesome 80s Prom. Danielle can be found next in the new musical Christmas In Hell at Urban Stages, taking Improv 401 at Upright Citizens Brigade, and developing the pilot she co-wrote.

Sam Urdang - The Juggler 

Sam Urdang is from Boulder, Colorado. He attended the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University, where he earned a BFA in Acting. He has been juggling for the past thirteen years.

story:
Short Summary

Uninvited is a short horror mystery film centered around four college girls who are visited by an unexpected guest. The girls learn that they can only see this guest one at a time, through a phone screen. Without taking a group selfie they may have never been able to realize they were not alone. 

Uninvited is our first funded film, and we want to kick it off with a bang! With your help this can be possible. 

What We Need & What You Get

In total, for this film to become a reality we need $1,072. Any contribution helps, and we really appreciate your help. 

We have fun perks that range from a thank you letter with a selfie of the cast and crew inside, to a digital copy of the film! ​We cannot wait to share this experience with you!

The Impact

when I say we can't do this without your help I really mean it.  

This short film is going to keep the viewer on the edge of his or her seat. I want this film to be different from anything I have made before. I know this film will soar, and with the carefully handpicked cast and crew this film will prove successful. 

Risks & Challenges

Shooting a horror mystery film is something I have never done before however I am always ready to learn and challenge myself. I carefully chose my cast and crew and strongly believe that we will be successful. This is also the first time I have this large of a budget. Now, in the grand scheme of things, $1072 is not large in the film world, but for me, it's new, and new is hard (but not impossible!). Our team will be able to succeed at making this film and I cannot wait to see everything come to life on the screen!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that money doesn't grow on trees, but we appreciate any help you can provide to us. Whether that's sharing this page, or showing a friend, we really want to get the word out about Uninvited so we can reach our goal!

Thank you from our team!

story:
Short Summary

This Little Light of Mine is a period drama that takes place during the American revolution with a little bit of fantasy mixed in.

During the American Revolution when colonial women were told they had no power, one girl finds her inner light to fight her way out of the dark.

This film is about Chelsea, a shy and shelter girl is seeking to be heard by those around her; especially when she discovers her family’s neighbor, Matthew secretly copying her father’s letter that tells the location of supplies for the Patriots. By nurturing the spirit in herself and others, Chelsea discovers she has power over fire and uses it to fight her way out of the dark and finally be heard.

We have an amazing cast and crew, including Chase Rubin as Director of Photography. LaTasha Bundy is composing the music score for the film. This short film is the graduate film school project of Laura Duval, who is working on her MFA in Film at the University of New Orleans. She has been working on commercials and short films since 2009 and has had a number of successful projects that have gone on to festivals, including “Courage Under Fire,” a short film about the Vietnam war.

 

What We Need & How You Can Help

Your contribution will help make this film possible! Even a few dollars will help buy a prop for set or part of a costume or a meal for an actor. And we have a lot of props and costumes and meals to buy to make this film possible. We also need help to pay for the entry fee to submit to festivals.

Making a period piece is more difficult than others as it requires everything on set to be from that time period. The costume design will have to include 1770s style, Middle Class America Colonial clothing. The set design and props have to look as though they belong in the 1770s, so costumes and props are harder to find and make and more expensive. Several props and costumes have already been donated but we still have many more we need.

Visual and special effects are expensive and take skilled people to pull them off. Visual Effects Artist Todd Schmidt has volunteered his time to do the visual effects with fire. However, there are also a number of special effects that require props and safety equipment to pull them off. We need your help to make this project safe and visually exciting!

We have a Steadicam but we would like to rent a Ronin to film with, along with lights and other film equipment to make this film more visually engaging. There are some specialty lights we would like to get because we are filming with candlelight and want the scenes to be lit to look more natural and realistic of that time period. The more you donate, the better lights and equipment we can use to make this film more visually engaging.

Because we are filming with candlelight we also have a lot of candles to buy to help light the set, set the scene, and help tell the story. So every dollar you donate is two more candles we need for set!

 

What You Get

Come join our team and help us make a movie!

We have T-shirts, buttons, stickers, and posters that were custom designed for this Indiegogo for “This Little Light of Mine” just for you to show the world you are letting your light shine!

If you want to see behind the scenes of “This Little Light of Mine,” we are making a special behind the scenes video just for our Indiegogo supporters who contribute $20. You will receive a special password that will allow you access to download this video at the end of post-production. This will include how we do some of the special effects and visual effects of the film!

We have an amazing cast, including Emily Blessey, Joey Alonzo, John Neisler, Olga Wilhelmine, Lisa Mackel Smith, Yvette Little, and John Raymond. You can receive a limited edition cast photo signed by some of the cast if you contribute $100 to help make this movie! But get them fast, we only have 20 available!

You can see your name on screen! We have a special thank you page in the credits for anyone who joins the team and contributes $200 or more.

Let the world know you are letting your light shine! We have a special limited edition package for those who want to contribute $500 to help make “This Little Light of Mine.” This is only for our Indiegogo supporters and only 20 will be made available. The package includes a custom design “This Little Light of Mine” T-shirt in your size and two custom designed “This Little Light of Mine” pins. You will also receive the “Behind the Scenes of This Little Light of Mine” video on DVD. You will also receive a cast photo signed by some of the cast.  It also includes “This Little light of Mine” custom stickers and a large movie poster that will only be available in this package!  Additionally, your name will be included on the special thank you page in the film’s credits. Come show the world you’ve joined our team to help make “This little Light of Mine”!

If you want to help promote your business or feel like a star, we will include your company’s graphic or your name on its own page in the credits if you contribute $1,000 or more.

Ever wanted to be on set and see what filming a movie is like? If you contribute $2,000 you will be invited to be on set during filming. You will get to meet the cast and crew and experience what set is like. This also includes meals on set with the team! (This does not include airfare or lodging)

If you want to feel even more a part of the team, you can have your very own Executive Produce credit if you contribute $5,000 or more. You will get to see your name at the beginning of the film on its own page as Executive Producer!

If we are able to raise more than our minimum goal, we will release a special video from the cast of “This Little Light of Mine” just for our Indiegogo Supporters!

 

The Impact

This film is to inspire young girls to keep trying to have a voice in the world. Even though sometimes people will push you down and bad things happen, if you keep trying, eventually you will be heard and make a difference. This film is also meant to educate people about the American Revolution time period and also entertain at the same time. A lot of people have forgotten about the founding of the United States. It was an extremely inspiring time where farmers, merchants, and other every-day ordinary people, who had very little experience in war, banded together to fight a larger, better funded, more experience, army in order to have a say in government. And the colonialists won! This film shows young girls how even the smallest girl, facing extraordinary difficulties, can make a difference.

 

Risks & Challenges

Many amazing people have volunteered their time and talent to help make this film so far. So even if we don’t make out goal, we will still find a way to make this film, but we will have to scale back and it will visually be a much better film if we can make our goal. Despite all of the creative and production challenges of this film, I believe with your help and all of the talented cast and crew who have volunteered their time on this project, we can create something that will catch people’s attention and inspire them.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this film with your friends and on Facebook. Like our Facebook Page at https://www.facebook.com/ThisLittleLightOfMineShines/. Only with your help and support can we make this film possible!

By nurturing the spirit in herself and others, Chelsea discovers she has power over fire and uses it to fight her way out of the dark and finally be heard.
We have an amazing cast and crew, including Chase Rubin as Director of Photography. LaTasha Bundy is composing the music score for the film. This short film is the graduate film school project of Laura Duval, who is working on her MFA in Film at the University of New Orleans. She has been working on commercials and short films since 2009 and has had a number of successful projects that have gone on to festivals, including “Courage Under Fire,” a short film about the Vietnam war.
 
What We Need & How You Can Help
Your contribution will help make this film possible! Even a few dollars will help buy a prop for set or part of a costume or a meal for an actor. And we have a lot of props and costumes and meals to buy to make this film possible. We also need help to pay for the entry fee to submit to festivals.
Making a period piece is more difficult than others as it requires everything on set to be from that time period. The costume design will have to include 1770s style, Middle Class America Colonial clothing. The set design and props have to look as though they belong in the 1770s, so costumes and props are harder to find and make and more expensive. Several props and costumes have already been donated but we still have many more we need.
Visual and special effects are expensive and take skilled people to pull them off. Visual Effects Artist Todd Schmidt has volunteered his time to do the visual effects with fire. However, there are also a number of special effects that require props and safety equipment to pull them off. We need your help to make this project safe and visually exciting!
We have a Steadicam but we would like to rent a Ronin to film with, along with lights and other film equipment to make this film more visually engaging. There are some specialty lights we would like to get because we are filming with candlelight and want the scenes to be lit to look more natural and realistic of that time period. The more you donate, the better lights and equipment we can use to make this film more visually engaging.
Because we are filming with candlelight we also have a lot of candles to buy to help light the set, set the scene, and help tell the story. So every dollar you donate is two more candles we need for set!
 
What You Get
Come join our team and help us make a movie!
We have T-shirts, buttons, stickers, and posters that were custom designed for this Indiegogo for “This Little Light of Mine” just for you to show the world you are letting your light shine!
If you want to see behind the scenes of “This Little Light of Mine,” we are making a special behind the scenes video just for our Indiegogo supporters who contribute $20. You will receive a special password that will allow you access to download this video at the end of post-production. This will include how we do some of the special effects and visual effects of the film!
We have an amazing cast, including Emily Blessey, Joey Alonzo, John Neisler, Olga Wilhelmine, Lisa Mackel Smith, Yvette Little, and John Raymond. You can receive a limited edition cast photo signed by some of the cast if you contribute $100 to help make this movie! But get them fast, we only have 20 available!
You can see your name on screen! We have a special thank you page in the credits for anyone who joins the team and contributes $200 or more.
Let the world know you are letting your light shine! We have a special limited edition package for those who want to contribute $500 to help make “This Little Light of Mine.” This is only for our Indiegogo supporters and only 20 will be made available. The package includes a custom design “This Little Light of Mine” T-shirt in your size and two custom designed “This Little Light of Mine” pins. You will also receive the “Behind the Scenes of This Little Light of Mine” video on DVD. You will also receive a cast photo signed by some of the cast.  It also includes “This Little light of Mine” custom stickers and a large movie poster that will only be available in this package!  Additionally, your name will be included on the special thank you page in the film’s credits. Come show the world you’ve joined our team to help make “This little Light of Mine”!
If you want to help promote your business or feel like a star, we will include your company’s graphic or your name on its own page in the credits if you contribute $1,000 or more.
Ever wanted to be on set and see what filming a movie is like? If you contribute $2,000 you will be invited to be on set during filming. You will get to meet the cast and crew and experience what set is like. This also includes meals on set with the team! (This does not include airfare or lodging)
If you want to feel even more a part of the team, you can have your very own Executive Produce credit if you contribute $5,000 or more. You will get to see your name at the beginning of the film on its own page as Executive Producer!
If we are able to raise more than our minimum goal, we will release a special video from the cast of “This Little Light of Mine” just for our Indiegogo Supporters!
 
The Impact
This film is to inspire young girls to keep trying to have a voice in the world. Even though sometimes people will push you down and bad things happen, if you keep trying, eventually you will be heard and make a difference. This film is also meant to educate people about the American Revolution time period and also entertain at the same time. A lot of people have forgotten about the founding of the United States. It was an extremely inspiring time where farmers, merchants, and other every-day ordinary people, who had very little experience in war, banded together to fight a larger, better funded, more experience, army in order to have a say in government. And the colonialists won! This film shows young girls how even the smallest girl, facing extraordinary difficulties, can make a difference.
 
Risks & Challenges
Many amazing people have volunteered their time and talent to help make this film so far. So even if we don’t make out goal, we will still find a way to make this film, but we will have to scale back and it will visually be a much better film if we can make our goal. Despite all of the creative and production challenges of this film, I believe with your help and all of the talented cast and crew who have volunteered their time on this project, we can create something that will catch people’s attention and inspire them.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this film with your friends and on Facebook. Like our Facebook Page at https://www.facebook.com/ThisLittleLightOfMineShines/. Only with your help and support can we make this film possible!

story:
For DENNIS BRECK every day is exactly the same. Stuck in a suburban rut of an unfulfilling job and a sexless marriage, Dennis lives his life unsatisfied and under stimulated. Constantly bombarded with endless amounts of porn sites, Instagram models, and hook up apps, Dennis feels that his chance to live the wild life he feels he deserves has passed him by.

When Dennis’ neighbor, the teenaged Adonis CONNER turns him on to an app that guarantees casual sex, his curiosity cannot be contained. Dennis downloads the app with the full intention of quickly deleting it, but his wife KATHERINE discovers it and they are for the first time forced to really evaluate their relationship. Are they boring? In a rut? Old?

Together, Dennis and Katherine agree to enter a world where they will satisfy each other's wildest sexual fantasies. Costumes, places, positions, toys; seemingly nothing is off limits. Their relationship tightens as they push each other further and further, and everyone is getting exactly what they think they want. 

Sometimes, things get taken too far too fast. Lines are crossed, people are hurt, and things cannot be undone. Are Dennis and Katherine able to deal with their real lives, once their fantasy lives have passed the point of no return?

Trunkfish is a sexy, sad, violent film that explores the scary reality of what happens when all your fantasies are brought to life.

 

 

We've spent about $65k of our own money to get the project this far and, straight up, we're tapped out. We have come from all over for the love and respect for each other and our devotion to film. 

There is so much goodwill and interested surrounding this project, but we simply can't self-fund the first step of getting this project out there and noticed. We need your help.

Hollywood isn't a huge fan of getting behind original content, we need to make a big splash. Think of it this way: Hollywood always wants a happy ending, but what if not all endings are happy but real.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If you want to help but can't afford to contribute money, you can still pitch in by sharing this campaign with as many people as possible: with friends and family, on your social media, and all over the Internet. Not only will you help raise awareness for this campaign, but you might help keep the dream of filmmaking alive for  an amazing team of people.

story:
Volly!! is a fan short film adaptation of "Haikyu!!" based upon specific chapters of the first tankōbon volume written by Haruichi Furudate. It tells the story of Sean Hindley, a student attending Gardner High School in order to join the volleyball team. His will to play will be tested by another Gardner volleyball player, Tobias Kirkman, who defeated him in a middle school game. Two people who hate each other must learn to play together, while overcoming their weaknesses and play to their strengths.

  • Our names our Robert and Trevor Benoit. We're twin brothers from a small town in Massachusetts that want to share an amazing manga and create something truly unique at the same time.
  • This campaign is about bringing people together through passion and kindness. Haikyu!! is a manga that focuses on teamwork in the hardest of circumstances. This is, in a way, about the process of our journey as content creators. We have faced extraordinary odds in getting a project off the ground as writers with little resources. What makes this project important to us is bringing as many people together and making a wonderful thing that we all are a part of.
  • How this happens is through money we have made independently through our day jobs and what you as contributors will assist in. While what we need is money to make the short as stunning as possible, we also need to make a change in the world as well. How we do this is by looking at the endgame of the campaign. All of the money that we raise, not used for the budget will be donated to charity. Every single penny. Any money or revenue made after the release will go towards the next project we create, if we go beyond what we need for that project, those funds too, will go to charity. This to us has nothing to do with money. It has everything to do with sharing our passions with the world and to make a difference in the process. All of the proceeds that exceed what is needed will go straight to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital because every child deserves a chance at all of the amazing things the world has to offer and we would be humbled to play even the smallest part.

This is as simple as it sounds. We need funding beyond the couple thousand we have raised on our own. In doing so, we will be able to deliver an amazing short film and you will be rewarded along with it.

  • We need around eight thousand dollars in order to afford the various parts essential in bringing "Volly!!" to life. The budget will go to the many different aspects of production from equipment rental, cast and crew payment, costume design, location confirmation, soundtrack development, along with post-production editing and visual effects. Trevor and I will not be receiving any payment ourselves while working on the short. In fact, we will be paying for our time there and taking time off of our day jobs. We are committed to utilizing all the funding as conservatively as possible.
  • The perks for you guys are something we are still working out. Potentially having hard-copy soundtracks for backers. Giving away costumes from the short to high backing contributors. Depends on how much we make!
  • If we don't reach our goal, we still are going to make the short. Everything we make will go towards the production and we will work our day jobs longer to make up the difference. At the end of the day, we want to project made and we guarantee that it will happen no matter what it takes!
  • Who knows, if the budget exceeds out wildest dreams and expectations, we could expand the concept into a fan feature instead of a short!!

Your contribution will make a difference! Not just for us! You're helping us contribute to a cause that means a great deal to us. 

  • What many people don't know is that it costs over $2 Million a day to keep the St. Jude Hospital up and running. Taking part in helping ensure that they are able to maintain operations and help the people that need it is something that goes deeper than just a short film. Our ultimate hope is to make a difference to the world while we are able to create something we love. 
  • We are just normal people like you. With challenges and dreams. We want to give other people that chance. This was our first belief the second we starting talking about the project and in the end we want to follow through with that promise.

There are various risks and obstacles that we may face on the way to achieving our goal. From not making the end goal of funding to unexpected barriers outside of our control, we understand that life can throw curve balls.

  • We are two post-undergraduate students with a dream. In spite of this, we have had the opportunity to visit film sets and speak with film producers about what needs to be taken into consideration during a production. Robert flew all the way to California just to learn the fundamental pieces of film financing from producer Franco Sama, who has served as a mentor to him.
  • Now to address the hurdles and risks. We have already discussed what happens if we don't make the goal, but we have yet to address the outside forces. If something were to happen to cast or crew members that would create a halt, we would go to great lengths to ensure the project's delivery. Whether it be awaiting reshoots or delaying the final product until ready. 
  • If there were such a time where the project simply could not happen, we would make sure that anything that comes from you would go to charity. That way you know that your money is not being pocketed, but is going to a good cause! We would contact the charity to make sure they are notified about every single backers name and that way you could be notified that your contribution was addressed to the right place. 

Not everyone has money to donate! That's okay! Sharing this with people you know and others who would be interested in sharing would mean more than we can even describe.

  • Do you have friends and family who love the original source material? Is there any one you know that might be able help gather attention to the project? You can help get the word out and make some noise about Volly!!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to bring this project to anyone, anywhere, anytime!

And that's all there is to it! 

At the end of the day, we are grateful for support in any way. That's what matters to us. Sometimes we can think, how is there a way for us to make a difference? Can we really change the world or change a life? The truth is you can! We can! Trevor and I, along with the cast and crew, want to change the world. This is just one of the ways we hope to. There are so many amazing people in this world that give without ever wanting anything in return. That's the message of our campaign. Give as a team, give as a planet.

The Benoit Brothers: WRITERS

Carlo Barbieri III: DIRECTOR

Robert Benoit: PRODUCER

----------

MAIN CAST

Trevor Benoit

Portraying Sean Hindley, one of the protagonists and Jumper/Middle Blocker. He is based upon Shoyo Hinata #10 in Haikyu!!

Kevin Green

Portraying David Sampson, a Senior and the captain of the GHS Volleyball Team. He is also the Wing Spiker. He is based upon Daichi Sawamura #1 in Haikyu!!

Juan A. Maldonado

Portraying Randy Tallen, the loud/abrasive Junior Wing Spiker. He is based upon Ryunosuke Tanaka #5 in Haikyu!!

Laura Whiteley

Portraying Kiara Sweeny, a Senior at GHS and the Men's Volleyball Team Manager. She is based upon Kiyoko Shimizu 3rd Year in Haikyu!!

Mikel Cravatta

Portraying Tobias Kirkman, one of the protagonists and the Setter for the GHS Volleyball Team. He is based upon Tobi Kageyama #9 in Haikyu!!

Tim Livingston

Kegan Samuel (Key), the Freshmen Main Middle Blocker. He is based upon Kei Tsukishima #11 in Haikyu!!

Peihu Wang

Portraying Ivan Takeda, Faculty Advisor and Temporary GHS Volleyball Coach. He is based upon Ittetsu Takeda in Haikyu!!

Herby Charmant

Portraying Steve Collins, the 3rd Year Setter, Pinch Server and Vice-Captian of the GHS Volleyball Team. He is based upon Kōshi Sugawara #2 in Haikyu!!

NOT CAST YET

Greg Thomas, the Freshmen Pinch Server. He is based upon Tadashi Yamaguchi #12 in Haikyu!!

 

CREW

-------------

CINEMATOGRAPHER

James Woodbury

 

CAMERA PRODUCTION ASSSISTANTS

Ellis Ducharme

Harron Wahid

 

GAFFER/LIGHTING DIRECTORS

Nick Jablonski

Dustin Howard

 

DRONE OPERATOR

Dan Hnatio

 

LOGO DESIGNS

BBock

 

MAKEUP ARTIST

Jade Nicole

 

HAIR STYLING

Tarah Dupuis

Rachel Appleton

 

TEASER SPECIAL THANKS

GHS Principal PAULA BOLGER, GHS Athletic Director DANIEL FORTE, and the GARDNER PUBLIC SCHOOLS for allowance of their facilities to shoot on location at the Gardner High School.

CAFE EDESIA for catering lunch during both days of shooting.

JOHN'S SPORTS SHOP for designing and crafting the jerseys/costumes.

​The RON BURTON TRAINING VILLAGE for the use of the volleyball poles for proper aesthetic use in the teaser.

Paul DeMeo from the TELEGRAM for visiting the set and working on a literary piece to support the project.

John Anctil and all of FASTLIGHTS for helping with the lighting/gaffer equipment needed to make the teaser visually come to life. Couldn't have done it without you.

Gardner City Hall Community Development and Planning Assistant Director JOSHUA CORMIER and the CITY OF GARDNER for the continued support on the project. It has been an honor to work in the city we grew up in and to show the importance of involving a local community.

Every single person who supported and believed in us throughout the process of bringing this teaser/project together. Without all of your kindness, love, and support, none of this would have been possible.

St. Jude Children's Research Hospital for giving every child the chance at a life they deserve and for showing that all donations matter. Goodness in this world comes from the heart and wanting to make a difference from that source. You have always been an inspiration to us and we hope to assist in that discourse of inspiration. The cast and crew of VOLLY!! thanks all of those that put the lives of all children ahead of their own. Children are the future and every child should have that future.

 

DISCLAIMER/THANKS

NOTHING'S CARVED IN STONE, "Around the Clock" - Sands of Time, DYNAMORD, 2010. The band (NCIS) and record label (Dynamord) own all rights to the lyrics and material. We do not own the song in any way and previous parties reserve all rights to the song/album. Song used for non-profit use in visual storytelling during the teaser and nothing more. 

We do not claim ownership on the story or characters of "Haikyu!!" They are the sole property of Haruichi Furudate, Shonen Jump, and VIZ Media. The use of these story elements and characters is merely for non-profit creative purposes. We hope to always represent 100% artistic integrity in regards to the use of these properties for this fan project. Thank you!

story:
A Dancer Dies Twice is a short film that looks into the personal story of two non-biological sisters, and represents their passions, trials and tests visually though ballet.

After tragedy befalls Hannah she finds herself living with an old friend, Nyesha and her mother, Orlena. Nyesha tries her best to make Hannah as comfortable as possible in her new home but Hannah's struggle with grief constantly overwhelms her.

Both girls have been practising ballet for many years. They look to ballet for strength and guidance, but the sudden change for the girls deeply affect their performances. This reveals Nyesha's jealously and Hannah's struggle with grief.

Will the girls rediscover the values of family before it's too late, or will they both succumb to the divide and fall apart?

A Dancer Dies Twice promises to be visually beautiful, with amazing locations, costumes and dance sequences. A story with thought-provoking moments with underlying themes that effect many performers across the world. This short film acts as a supportive piece towards increasing diversity in the ballet world.

 

Lauren Thorpe: Director

Hardworking, energetic and a people-person, Lauren is a natural leader who recognises the skills and importance of every single crew member in the team. Always a creative; she is a musician, and previously an actress and artist, and therefore has an understanding of multiple art forms and how they unify within filmmaking. She has directed throughout university and is able to create a rapport with actors that is professional, rewarding and fun. A Dancer Dies Twice is a project that Lauren wants to use as a platform to highlight a number of issues and develop two strong characters whose struggles are very real, all whilst hailing to the beauty, prowess and opportunities ballet gives people across the world.

Bethany Lark: Producer

Bethany is an enthusiastic person when it comes to filmmaking. Having already produced a short studio drama, she is enthusiastic about producing her final year film. She enjoys producing as it allows her to experience each part of the filmmaking process. She’s excited to work with an upcoming and talented team to produce an exciting film. 

Craig Patterson: Writer

Craig is a hard worker and passionate filmmaker, with an interest in script writing. Having many writing credits under his belt, he is ready to give his all to this project. He is a firm believer that script is the most important part of filmmaking. He is working closely with the team to make sure the script is at its best. Having a passion for writing and understanding of character development. He is keen to bring this dramatic story to life.​

Max Ward: Director of Photography 

Max is the Director of Photography and head of VFX in post production. His role on set is to transform the script into visual art. During the pre-production process he will be responsible for creating location recce’s, storyboards and shot lists. Max hopes to use a range of grips equipment in the film to get the best movement in each scene. Part of the film is a ballet performance and Max wants to single out the protagonist by using the right lighting and high zoom lenses to create a large depth of field. Additionally to this, the inspirations behind some of his ideas are from the films, Citizen Kane and 2001 Space Odyssey.

Lauren Vincent: 1st Assistant Director & Editor

Lauren has spent her time getting experience as a first assistant director and editor on a number of film projects. She is extremely enthusiastic about filmmaking, especially in these two roles. She will be the Directors right-hand woman making sure the artistic vision of the film is fully achieved. She also is excited to work closely with a cast who have a strong background in dance and learn more about the performing art form. Lauren is also head editor of A Dancer Dies Twice and will use all previous experience as an editor to help create a visually stunning final film. Lauren loves how films can masterfully craft a powerful social message such as Jordan Peele’s film, 'Get Out’ and is inspired to include a similar incisive message in A Dancer Dies Twice.

Jelyseen Chung: Sound Recordist & Editor

Originality is the key to creativeness and sound is the key aspect of film. Jelyseen has undertaken the role of sound designer on the production A Dancer Dies Twice. The sound designer is responsible for diegetic and non-diegetic sound that is being heard within the production. While Jelyseen has worked previously on sound, for other productions, she is well aware of the sort emotions A Dancer Dies Twice will convey to the audience. To make sure this process runs smoothly Jelyseen will be collaborating with other creatives such as the music majors, to come up with an original sound for an original film.​

Shebani Walia: Lighting Director & Colourist

Shebani is a proactive and energetic individual on set, who loves to create something with meaning. She has many roles under her belt, including producer, editor and cinematographer. She is always trying to improve her craft and to become a better storyteller.  She has a good eye for colour and is looking forward to exploring different lighting techniques to help create the right look and feel for the film. Shebani will be closely working together with the DOP and director to make this film visually appealing.

Doriana Hax: Production Designer

Creative and passionate, Doriana has a great love for film making and the collaboration of different creative people it entails. Enthusiastic about design as well as the visual aesthetic of film, Production Designer is a well suited role. Having previous experience in garment making and design she will be creating suited costumes for the characters of A Dancer Dies Twice which will help in illustrating the message of the film as well as add to it's individual feel. Another critical part of her role will be concerning props and ensuring the location looks as realistic as possible and for this she will collect an array of props to be placed in the different locations carefully selected. A Dancer Dies Twice is a film Doriana is very passionate about as she previously spent a number of years studying Ballet and has seen first hand the issues that surround It.

The money kindly donated to us will be divided into many different departments, all essential in the creation of A Dancer Dies Twice. Most of the money will be spent on our hard working actors and production design, making the locations and actors look visually stunning. 

The money raised will also go into location fees and distribution - helping us put A Dancer Dies Twice into film festivals! It's also important that we keep some money aside just incase something happens that we didn't plan for!

Every contribution towards our film is greatly appreciated but if you can't donate you can still help. We need you help sharing this page, it will help us to spread awareness of A Dancer Dies Twice.

Thanks for all your help! If you want to get in touch please email us at: adancerdiestwice@gmail.com, or check out our social media pages to keep up to date with our pre-production:

  • facebook
  • twitter
  • instagram 
  • snapchat - @ADDTFilm

story:
Hi, my name is Victor Hernandez. I am a video director born in Boston, Massachusetts and raised in Orange, California. Most of my career is centered around doing music videos for various artist spanning more than 8 years. Although I love doing music videos and various promotional videos, my heart and dream is to direct feature length films. Funny thing is that through doing music videos for fellow Orange County artists LGC, I met 4th Beats, and in turn, met Vel The Wonder. Vel and 4th together make up the duo called Melotonics. With their first self titled album release, which was highly praised and received, I had the honor to film two music videos for it. In a conversation with Vel and 4th, we talked about pushing the music videos from simple performance based videos, to more thought out storylines that weave into the video itself. After we did the video for ‘Stuck’, my mind dove into a creative thought overload that made the entire album into an actual short film. I love what Melotonics did on this album. Having themes of love, pain and heartbreak, all wrapped up in a 1950’s songbird feel, it had me come up with the character of Mela. A young girl trying to find love after a horrible break-up, which had a touch of me in it, for I had recently gone through a similar situation.

 

I wrote the script which was just 10 pages long at first. After talking to a close mentor and friend of mine, Jared Lundy, he found an amazing writer, Jo Hannah Afton, who was willing to take up the script and expand it to 30 pages. Jo Hannah did a beautiful job at making this story into what it is today, but before we could get the script into pre-production, life got in the way. A lot of the planning for the short film actually took place 2 years ago, and like a fine wine with time, it got even better. Coming back to the project now, everything has organically fallen into place. We are proud to say that we have officially teamed up with CheckMate Films to move Melotonics from the pages, to the screen!

 

The reasons for making this film is many: life long dreams to direct, for the fans of Melotonics, a drive to produce more creative content, to put out a heartfelt story; but most of all, to empower those with self love. The story of Melotonics, as stated above, follows a young woman who finds her fiancé cheating on her. In trying to forget the hurt, Mela goes off on an adventure to San Francisco, where she meets a man.  I hope that through this film, the audience can pull on the experiences that Mela goes through and the growth she gains as she finds love in herself, to implement those qualities in their own lives.

 

Whether it’s trying to find “the one”, understanding and empathy from parents, or simply feeling wanted, it’s a chase that unfortunately catch people feeling empty and/or still wanting more. I myself have experienced that going from relationship to relationship, and having a hard time seeing eye to eye because I had no understanding of where I stood myself as an individual. One must feel confident, and love themselves for who they are. I strongly believe that that’s something society lacks now and days. With people searching for the “LIKES” and “FOLLOWS”, many gauge their happiness on social media status, but what happens when all those things are done and gone? If you love yourself already and have a clear understanding of who you are, when all those temporary materialistic things have withered away, you still have that love and comfort that is inside you. I know that might sound cheesy or cliche´, but take it for me, it’s true. It comes from being real and honest with yourself, so that you may be truly honest and comfortable with others. It’s ok to feel angry, upset, scared or worried; but don’t let those emotions define you. I had a very close cousin of mine who took his own life because he could not cope with the pain that the world put on him. To this day it is hard to breath when I talk about him, remembering that no matter how much love my family and I gave to him, it wasn’t enough to stop him from taking committing suicide.

 

I am so grateful that through the help of many friends and colleagues, this film is where it’s at. And even so, we cannot do it without your help! With your donations we can raise the budget necessary to push this script into production, and onward to completion. We have personal incentives for all those who participate in donating to the Melotonics Short Film, one of them being exclusive Behind The Scenes footage of the production process. To become a part of our contributing community, go to our website to find our indiegogo. Melotonics, the production team and I want to personally thank you for your time and heart in contributing to this short film.
