story:
PENDULUM FILMS, Who we are:

"Our mission is to create high quality Family entertainment. Great stories, well told!"

thebonfielddickson.com for more about the project!

Dave Olson - Founder  I have been an actor for over 30 years. I've been involved with every aspect of theater and film both on set,and behind the scenes. I've also been an avid canoeist since I went to Camp Otter as a kid and have been traveling  there most of my life. Yes! Camp Otter existed from 1910 to 1970, just outside the wonderful little town of Dorset, Ontario. Algonquin Park is just 30 miles north. It was from here and a lifetime of growth that the idea for this film was born. 

The Bonfield-Dickson is a real place. You can google it, people talk about it. Some refer to it as the Dickson -Bonfield, either way, it's the portage from Bonfield Lake to Dickson Lake, and at 3.25 miles long, it's one of the longest in the park. Being on a canoe trip requires team work and a lot of joking around!! Seriously though, when your out in the wilderness for up 10 days with just your food, equipment and fellow campers, you learn about working together for a common goal. It's the perfect metaphor for telling our story about coming of age, overcoming obstacles, Friendship and Family, and, about finding Faith. Thomas Porter is faced with challenges and decisions about life all teenagers face. Crossing The Bonfield-Dickson portage and how he meets a "challenge" he's taken on, is the major point in the story, but not the only point. We have this wonderful problem of having more material than we can shoot for a 2hr film! So we have our work cut out for us to make this as we envision it now. When was the last time we had a kids movie with real characters, great story telling with a positive message and fantastic scenery? Well, it's time we had one and with your help we're going to make this film!

 

Jeffrey Olson- Story Development, Writer.  Proud to have him as my younger, but just as talented, Brother! He has a degree in education and has extensive experience working with troubled and special needs kids. We spent 3 summers together at Camp Otter . Our memories of the camp, canoe trips, friendships  and especially the "characters" we remember provide us with a very deep well to draw from. His input towards development of our lead, Thomas Porter, and the journey we take with him and all the other quirky, fun characters, is invaluable.

 

Jason Richards- Assistant Director, Writer.  I met Jason in 2010 at our church where he was Creative Director of our Children's Theater and Ministry. We've had many, long conversations about the need for quality films with a positive, faith based message. As my dream of the film grew to the point of making the promotional, Jason, has been instrumental all the way from finalizing the script, bringing in the camera crew, recording sound, editing and being a fresh set of eyes and ideas. Jason has an MA in Communications with an emphasis in Cinema/ Television Directing and also a BA in Business Administration and Portuguese from the University of Florida. He and his wife Lynn, A Regent University Grad with an MFA in Acting, are founders of Rich Theater (richtheater.org) which teaches and mentors young people here in Virginia Beach, VA.

Libby Rogers Hirsch- Project Coordinator.  Libby is a retired Educator and Art Therapist. I met her there my first summer in 1967 and we've been friends since then! She came there in 1955 as a 9 month old with her parents who were running the camp and was there every summer till it closed, sadly, in 1970. She is a treasure trove of camp history and here memories and stories are a great contribution our film and will be a valuable member of our production team.

There's too many kids without good roll models and mentors in there lives, this is a film for them. It's also a film for families because it re-enforces the values of what a strong, nuclear, family can be.  Help us bring this positive, fun, adventurous film to reality and fund our project

Thank you. God Bless You!

Dave Olson

story:
Angus ‘Gus’ Denton lives a ‘normal’ serial killer life. He works as a security guard but in his free time he loves to kill. Being obsessed with documenting his murder streak in his diary, Gus takes polaroids of his victims which he uses as excerpts in his diary. So why does he refuse to let people into his home? Because it’s a crime scene. Gus reveals to his mother Meryl (a bed-bound occupant in his flat) that he has bought a lottery ticket for her to play. 

SURPRISE! He hits the jackpot. Disequilibrium unfolds as reporters find out about his win and hunt him down for an ‘inside’ scoop. One reporter attempts to barge into his flat. Gus tries his utmost to keep them out. All he wants is to live his regular life, but it just so happens that he is now in the spotlight. Panicked, he does everything he can to avoid them from entering his home. Unlucky for him – he confesses to a kill in front of his mother. 

Our film deals with the theme of morality. Our lead character Gus struggles to find a moral compass as we explore his emotional side. The moment he gets caught, he shows remorse – begging the question; is he sorry that he got caught or that he did it? A strong theme within our film is survival. An 'individual vs. human' conflict is presented at Gus' hands. Although, the conflict at hand is not physical, he struggles to maintain an equilibrium as the reporter urges to get inside of his flat, ultimately leaving him exposed to his crime scene. 
With a secured main location, we are pleased to say that we have saved a bit of money from our budget. Three of our crew members are renting a private flat which echoes the character of Gus through and through. We knew that this was the location we should use if it was available to us, and luckily – it is! 

We are looking to raise £2,500 to help us fund this production and we need your help to do so. It  would mean the absolute world to us if you could support us on this journey! We feel our film has a unique story and we want to execute it properly. (Excuse the pun)

If you decide to donate to our film, this is how we would spend the money! 

We want to ensure that we are paying our actors a fair wage. We have various expenses to cover such as art department, catering to feed cast and crew, and transport for our equipment. We want to create a professional production which will reflect our work ethic and passion for filmmaking. 

Most of our budget will be going towards the actors and art department. This is to ensure that the look of the film does justice to our story. We have a separate budget for PPE which we will provide to cast and crew on set in order to stay safe during the production.

If you are able to contribute anything, we really appreciate it. If you are not in a position where you can donate - you can simply help by sharing our page to people that you know and join us on this ride!  

Peter has had experience in script-writing for various Film and TV projects. He has a keen interest in British comedy and its dialogue - something that he applied in this script. While the film serves a dark theme of murder, he was able to apply his comedic skills within the dialogue. The use of British slang allows the audience to feel a sense of relief as they are subjected to such a malevolent character. Isaac is focused on conveying clear emotional stakes that the audience can be invested in without having any allegiance towards Gus. Drawing inspiration from his background as an editor, he is aware that the story is foretold in many aspects of filmmaking. He will be working very closely with our actor to make sure that the audience can relate to him on an emotional level, yet want him to be caught for his wrongdoings.
As the producer of the film, Karolina has been working hard to create a professional on-set experience for both the cast and the crew. She has had experience in managing groups of people which has been an extremely helpful skill to utilise in film production. Her priority has been to make sure that the film is executed properly in a safe environment.    Indro's experience in the camera department has allowed him to acquire technical knowledge that enhances his creative vision. It will allow him to design the best visual look to better portray the core and theme of the film. He has been working with production design in order to build the right environment for the story - creating a juxtaposition as the mood of the film changes. Sam has been getting to know the character of Gus and deconstructing his mannerisms, sense of style, and home life. His aim is to create a space that screams Gus through continued research, creative workshopping, and by working closely with the Director and DoP. We trust Sam to really delve into the mind of our lead character, and weave a world around him that disturbs and entices. Vilte has experience as a sound recordist, mixer and designer in various film and TV projects.  Her goal is to create an immersive soundscape that builds tension as the story unfolds, focusing on the clash between Gus’ flat and the outside world that invades it. A big fan of serial-killer/psychopath films, Vilte hopes to provide a real auditory experience when it comes to the daily activities of a serial killer, and more.  Our editor Victoria will be working closely with the director to create a world that allows us to get lost in. As the audience feels sorry for our main character, Victoria's objective is to maintain the feeling of wanting Gus to pay for his actions. She will achieve this through different pacing tactics and colour-grading, as well as focusing on bringing the smaller details of the character's world to life.  

At this current moment in time, we are working hard to create a COVID-19 safe environment for both the cast and crew. Each member of the crew is working towards completing a Coronavirus Basic Awareness on Production training by ScreenSkills. Our producer also holds a PASS in APA Covid-19 Assessment test where she can be considered for COVID Supervisor roles on set. We have been working on completing COVID-19 declaration forms for cast and crew to sign, as well as documents that have strict procedures on set. 

We will be providing our cast and crew with PPE on set, covered in our budget. This is to ensure that everyone can stay safe, have access to face-masks, sanitiser, visors and gloves. It is very important for us to maintain a high standard of health and safety - which we have been working on since day 1 of our production. 

             

www.instagram.com/making.a.killing

   www.facebook.com/MAKshortfilm
story_txt: Angus ‘Gus’ Denton lives a ‘normal’ serial killer life. He works as a security guard but in his free time he loves to kill. Being obsessed with documenting his murder streak in his diary, Gus takes polaroids of his victims which he uses as excerpts in his diary. So why does he refuse to let people into his home? Because it’s a crime scene. Gus reveals to his mother Meryl (a bed-bound occupant in his flat) that he has bought a lottery ticket for her to play. SURPRISE! He hits the jackpot. Disequilibrium unfolds as reporters find out about his win and hunt him down for an ‘inside’ scoop. One reporter attempts to barge into his flat. Gus tries his utmost to keep them out. All he wants is to live his regular life, but it just so happens that he is now in the spotlight. Panicked, he does everything he can to avoid them from entering his home. Unlucky for him – he confesses to a kill in front of his mother. Our film deals with the theme of morality. Our lead character Gus struggles to find a moral compass as we explore his emotional side. The moment he gets caught, he shows remorse – begging the question; is he sorry that he got caught or that he did it? A strong theme within our film is survival. An 'individual vs. human' conflict is presented at Gus' hands. Although, the conflict at hand is not physical, he struggles to maintain an equilibrium as the reporter urges to get inside of his flat, ultimately leaving him exposed to his crime scene. With a secured main location, we are pleased to say that we have saved a bit of money from our budget. Three of our crew members are renting a private flat which echoes the character of Gus through and through. We knew that this was the location we should use if it was available to us, and luckily – it is! We are looking to raise £2,500 to help us fund this production and we need your help to do so. story:
Short Summary

While We Wait tells the story of Jade and her brother, Lanre, trying to rekindle their sibling bond whilst waiting to see if their mother manages to pull through intensive care.

Faced with the dilemma of their mother’s looming death, semi-estranged siblings Jade and Lanre are stuck together in an ICU waiting room in the middle of the night. Despite once being thick as thieves, Lanre and Jade have grown apart massively due to his busy life, his demanding relationship and his inability to come to terms with his sister’s sexual assault. As they pass through the long night, hard truths and memories unfold, and the hope of rekindling their close sibling bond resurfaces.

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to donations from our Cast & Crew we have been able to make a very moving short film. Now, to get this piece of art out to as many festivals as possible, we need you!  With your help and financial contributions, we can submit While We Wait to numerous cutting-edge festivals worldwide so many audiences have the opportunity to watch this incredibly important film.

In return for your contribution, you will be the first to know of screenings of the project and on request, will have access to a director's cut screening of the project.

The Impact

I can count on one hand how many films I’ve watched as an adult that has a brother and sister relationship or even a sibling relationship at its core, meanwhile, the stuff I watched growing up centred around these relationships – Narnia, Mrs Doubtfire, Cheaper by The Dozen, That’s So Raven even Frozen.  It’s important to me as a writer, as a sister to two brothers to show these relationships existing past childhood.

While We Wait was produced and filmed in London by a fantastic group of creatives.  We are proud to say that we were able to assemble a Cast & Crew of predominantly Black and Asian descent, as over 75% of our Cast & Crew were BAME.  We are also telling a story with mixed-race Nigerian characters, exploring difficult subject matter, particularly sexual assault in Nigeria, the country in which I grew up.   Records of sexual assault are hard to come by, but a 2019 study found that between the years of 1973 and 2019 – that’s 46 years, there have only been 65 rape convictions in Nigeria, half of which took place after 2015.  Only 2 states out of the 36 have a Sex Offender’s registry, which are extremely hard to come by anyway.  Where I come from, rape is a part of many women’s unspoken histories and even present.  We need to talk about it and we need to raise awareness about it.  It was important for me to do that with While We Wait.

It is so important for us to raise these funds so we can get this film out to as many festivals as possible to not only share a very moving story but to also raise debate and awareness around very important topics.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that times are especially tough right now and if you can't donate for one reason or another, all hope is not lost, you can still help While We Wait.  Check out our website www.whilewewaitshortfilm.com and share our website with your friends, family and followers on social media.  You can also follow us on Instagram @whilewewaitshortfilm and Facebook While We Wait Short Film and share our posts there too.  Thank-you so much for everything you're doing to help the future of While We Wait.

story:
Story Synopsis

The Goatman is a classic monster mystery intertwined with a family horror drama. What is supposed to be an emotional reunion turns into a night of terror. Centering on a dysfunctional set of siblings and their significant others, the movie explores the dangers of letting resentments fester over the course of a horrifying supernatural attack. Inspired by fragments of various legends, The Goatman introduces new mythical attributes and lore to the ancient, terrifying cryptid.

Who are we?

We are Clay, Levi, and Hope Butner, three sibling filmmakers and creators of The Goatman.

The idea for The Goatman feature film was developed in 2010 when we first heard tales of The Goatman legend. After getting degrees in film and creative writing, we are finally able to tell our story and make this project happen.

We have always loved movies and we've been making them together since we were kids. And Garrett Poladian, one of our childhood friends, who after years of studying theatre and performing in New York, will be joining us as our lead actor! 

Garrett Poladian, Lead Actor

The rest of our crew is comprised of friends, family, and peers who have an amazing amount of experience and generosity with their time, and are all incredibly passionate about making this movie happen. 

Corrinne Mica, lead actor

 

Marissa Pattullo, Actor

 

Joshua Christopher, actor

 

Madeleine Masson, actor

 

Tanner Lacoste, Director of Photography

 

Brenton Peplinski, SFX Makeup Artist

 

Nicole Brinck, Production Manager

 

Darren Taylor, Set Builder

 

Budget

You support towards this film will go towards the following:

  • CAMERA &  LIGHTING EQUIPMENT - a large portion of our budget will be going towards getting some of the best equipment possible to make this movie gorgeous.
     
  • CAST & CREW - even with a number of people providing a significant amount of time for free, we want to provide as much payment as possible to the amazing artists we have working on our production.
     
  • SET & LOCATION - our experienced set designer is donating his time to help us construct an amazing set for our story. Though having the movie all take place in one general area, there are a few separate locations that require money to build or a trailer that we're renting.
     
  • WARDROBE & MAKEUP - wardrobe costs will be kept at a minimum since the characters stay in the same clothes over the course of the movie, so we're putting a good deal of our budget into makeup and creature design and working with a fantastic artist to make our story as scary as possible. 
     
  • COVID SAFETY - ensuring that everyone has access to PPE, sanitizer, and other equipment to ensure everyone's health is incredibly important.
     
  • INSURANCE - because things happen.

Select a perk on the right-hand side, or simply make a contribution!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to donate any money, there are other ways you can help us out!

  • Shoutout to us on social media
  • Continue to follow us and watch the movie when it's released
  • Sharing any expertise you may have in the filmmaking world

story:
What is It Only Hurts When I Laugh?

After learning one of his regulars signed him up for a stand-up gig, Isaac, a shy 20 something realizes he’s got what it takes to kill in comedy — literally!

This short film highlights the complications and debilitations that self-doubt has on a person when reaching for their lifelong dreams. In a strange twist of fate, Isaac realizes he DOES have what it takes to kill an audience. This storyline, developed through comedy, portrays the importance of self-respect, self-esteem, creativity, confidence, and the courage to reach for a dream — no matter what's stopping you.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Currently, we are seeking funds for the production of this short film. We will use your contributions for Cast/Crew Payment, Food, Props, and Wardrobe. We appreciate any donation you are able to make, and for the contribution amounts, below, we will be offering special incentives.

  • $5 contribution: Our eternal gratitude & newsletter with updates on production.
  • $10 contribution: An Instagram story shoutout that will stand against the test of time.
  • $15 contribution: A signed, one of a kind, behind the scenes photo.
  • $20 contribution: A personal thank-you card signed by the crew
  • $50 contribution: The printed film screenplay — signed by the writer and directors, and a personal thank-you card signed by the entire crew.
  • $75 contribution: A "Special Thanks" credit on the film.
  • $100 contribution: Digital print poster, printed screenplay, and a personal thank-you card signed by the crew.
  • $250 contribution: An "Executive Producer" credit.
  • $400 contribution: ALL PERKS AND ACCESS TO OUR PRIVATE SCREENING (Date TBD), Plus a special Q&A session with the crew!

 

The Impact

As a crew of college students, your contribution to the creation of this low-budget film is PRICELESS, so thank you. Any monetary gift you are able to make helps us fund the film properly, and your donation goes directly to the costs of casting, creating, filming, editing, and producing this film.

We hope that It Only Hurts When I Laugh will be selected for film festivals, which we'll delightfully share with you as we go on this journey together!

 

Meet our crew!

Directors: Armaan and Ahmed Sultan

We are Puerto Rican, Pakistani twin brothers from East Chicago, Indiana. Currently, we're both at Flashpoint Chicago earning our BFA in Cinema with a discipline in directing. We eat, sleep, and breathe entertainment. Both on set and off, we strive to build communities and networks with our films. As you'd imagine twins would, we work extremely well together. We thank you for your generosity by donating to help us bring this film to life!

 

Writer/Producer/Cinematographer: Chris Bakewell

Hailing from Chicago, Chris Bakewell is taking the next step in pursuing a successful career in the film industry. Mainly focusing on cinematography, Chris loves bringing great ideas to life in the most visually stunning ways possible. Chris' main goal when writing It Only Hurts When I Laugh was to inspire others to follow their passion — and not hide from the things they love.

 

Assistant Director: Dennis Villanueva

Dennis Villanueva is a fresh graduate of Flashpoint Chicago and is just now breaking into the film industry primarily working as a Script Supervisor. Dennis can be described as hard-working, dedicated, and is always available to help. 

 

1st Assistant Camera: Marco Richard

Marco Richard is currently studying at Flashpoint Chicago with a discipline in cinematography. He has been working on his craft for 4 years strong and is currently advancing towards larger projects, including It Only Hurts When I Laugh. Marco is consistently a positive force on set and is truly a great addition to the team.

 

Key Grip: Ben Hart

Ben is an ecstatic and diligent director from Mount Prospect, IL. Always up for a challenge, Ben loves working behind the scenes and is determined to be the best Key Grip he can be for this production.

 

Editor and Social Media Manager: Ronni August

Ronni August is an award-winning independent filmmaker who specializes in screenwriting, directing, and editing. She will be graduating at the end of 2021 with a BFA in Cinema from Flashpoint Chicago. With several years of experience under her belt, she is excited to edit IOHWIL.

 

Production Assistant: Akhenaton "Kenny" Achampong

Kenny is an aspiring music video director who is currently on course for completing his Associate of Applied Science in film with an emphasis on editing and production. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute money. That doesn't mean you can't help, though! 

  • Head over to our Instagram and give it some love: https://www.instagram.com/iohwil.film/
  • Give us a like/share on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/iohwil.film
  • Join our Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/180340110552650
  • Share THIS campaign!

Again, from the bottom of our hearts, THANK YOU!

Production Assistant: Akhenaton "Kenny" Achampong

Kenny is an aspiring music video director who is currently on course for completing his Associate of Applied Science in film with an emphasis on editing and production. 
 
 
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute money. That doesn't mean you can't help, though! 

Head over to our Instagram and give it some love: https://www.instagram.com/iohwil.film/

Give us a like/share on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/iohwil.film

Join our Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/180340110552650

Share THIS campaign!

Again, from the bottom of our hearts, THANK YOU!

story:
ABOUT OUR FILM

Welcome to our campaign! We are so thrilled that you are here and have shown interest in 'The Lake Man'. We are very passionate about this film and telling this adventurous story.  We want you to be a part of the process and come along for the ride! 

 

The Plot:

'The Lake Man' takes place in the year 2030, where a black hole looms in the sky over a fictional lake called 'Lake Oyarsa'. An army veteran who suffers from PTSD, James Hartfield, has vivid nightmares of his astrophysicist wife's death and of a mysterious homeless man who has coordinates to a portal created by the black hole's energy. James' wife, Ava, studies the black hole, and a government task force is out to steal her research in order to use the portal's time bending capabilities to manipulate the past. When James learns that these nightmares are actually happening in real time, he sets out to uncover why they involve the Lake Man, who the Lake Man is, and what he wants with the portal. 

 

Director's Statement:

Greetings ! My name is Joe Simon, and I am the writer and director of 'The Lake Man'. The fact that you are reading this is so exciting. This idea for this film came out of a desire to make to make a film with my friends, and the fact that we are HERE launching this campaign is just awesome.

The Lake Man was an idea that kept floating through my mind throughout 2020, in the middle of the COVID-19 pandemic. I was on the lake with a friend and the idea just kind of hit me. A story about a mysterious man who lives on the lake. But the concept only evolved. I love modern indie sci fi films and I have always wanted to write and direct one! But one that was authentic to me, and the films I love. 

Our film has taken inspiration from films such as 'Mud', 'Logan', 'Interstellar, 'Arrival', and so much more! 

I feel that this short could be something really special. Even though it will be short in length, it will be jam packed with action, suspense, stunning visual effects, emotion, and excitement. We really believe we have a unique story to tell, and one that will stand out from other shorts.

 

What We Need

​We're especially excited for this campaign because we want to partner with supporters who believe in our team, are inspired and intrigued by our story, and who want to see us turn it into a unique and entertaining film. 

The Lake Man will be filmed at Lake Allatoona, about 30 minutes north of Atlanta, Georgia. Our cast and crew live in and around Atlanta, so our transportation and lodging expenses will be relatively low to non-existent. Our highest costs will be in our wages and hospitality. It's important to us that our cast and crew feel valued, comfortable, and fed.

Given our initial estimated schedule, we're aiming for a total wages expense of $3,000, $1,000 for food and refreshments, and $2,000 for equipment/props/costuming/post-production. A $100 donation, for example, would cover refreshments for one day of filming. A donation of $200 would cover a meal for one day, or the cost of a cast member's wages for one day.  A donation of $500 to $1,000 would pay for a significant portion of our cinematography and lighting equipment costs. 

In the unfortunate case that we do not reach our goal in the allotted time for this campaign, we will have to postpone creating The Lake Man until we have the means to give it the attention it needs.

  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to give to our campaign financially, there are other ways you can help! We encourage you to make some noise about The Lake Man on social media and amongst your family and friends. We'd love it if you could share a link to this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools. 

 

Thank you so much for your attention to our campaign! We hope you will consider giving to The Lake Man and helping us create this film.

story:
*First poster for the film*

What is it like to live as a teenager in today's society? In our opinion it can be truly awful, at least it's not easy.

 

Here are links were you can follow and read more about us.

Website, Instagram, Facebook, Vimeo, Youtube

 

The story follows a 18-year-old Aurora struggling to find herself after all the pressure coming from her friends, family and the society. Battling with her own mind she struggles to make herself happy. It is easier said than done. She might not be in the middle of every drama but as a bystander she is effected by what others are saying and doing, even though she wouldn't like to be.

This story is told by 31 young filmmakers and film enthusiast. All of us have one goal with this film; we want to tell real stories about life as a teenager in today's society. We want to bring up the real struggles and thoughts young people go through from ages 18-26.

We are making this film to bring awareness about bearings young people go through every day around the world, such as mental health issues and peer pressure. 

This film is about 45 minutes to 60 minutes long and is made in Finnish but is subtitled in English. 

This story is close to our directors and script writers Oona Glans' life, and the idea to create a film with only young filmmakers and film enthusiast who has just gone through those hard years of becoming an "adult" came from her.

"After graduating from High School and pursuing career in film industry I started following more and more films that showed what life as a youngster is, I noticed how those films didn't show the real thoughts and feelings my friends and I went through. I started to talk about this discovery of mine with my filmmaker friends who all had the same feeling. Then came the idea to tell a story that would show the real world of young people."

 

 

Let us introduce you our leading crew members!

Let us introduce you our leading actress and actor

 

Color inspiration 

WHERE WE ARE PLANING TO USE THE MONEY:

We need this money mainly for the filming equipment. We are planing of buying the equipment so it is cost effective.  Next bigger part of the budget will go to catering. We intend to give our crew a possibility to have something to eat and drink during the filming, because everyone is volunteering in this project. Rest of the money will mostly go to marketing fees and  transportation costs. 

THE REASONS TO SUPPORT THIS FILM:

  1. It's a completely new approach to tell a story about young people and it is something that we feel like has never been done before. This is a film we would want to see ourselves.
  2. This film gives a unique opportunity to youngsters to say things out loud that they haven't been able to say.
  3. Even tough we don't have years of experience, we are new generation with a new approach to film making, without forgetting the traditional ways.
  4. This film gives experience and a chance for young filmmakers to work in a bigger project and gain more experience. This helps these filmmakers to work in future projects.  (We just wanna say that every one of us is doing this voluntarily without getting any money out of this.)
  5. And one of the most important reasons: All the extra money out of this and the unused money from the production, will be donated to charities and different parties that support mental health and prevent exclusion of young people. (The charities will be announced later during the production. We also want to hear from people backing us.)

 

WHAT HAVE WE DONE SO FAR?

So far we have finished the script to be fully ready for filming. We also have the whole crew together and have casted the main roles for the film. We have also agreed to cooperate with Helsinki Media Arts Upper Secondary School. Many of the crew members are students from this school and for some of us it is our old school.  Currently we are in the middle of the pre-production. You can follow our process from our website and social media. From which you can  see behind the scenes videos and photos. From our website you can follow our "Production Blog" where all the crew members are able to share their thoughts. 

 

Here are links were you can follow and read more about us.

Website, Instagram, Facebook, Vimeo, Youtube

story:
Get The Girl Feature Film Production

Sebastain "Bash" Danye, a legendary gun for hire hangs up his weapon to retire peacefully with his ‘it’s complicated’ partner Renee. Their quiet lives are soon interrupted when they find an unconscious woman on their property, Maddie. While nursing her back to health, some bad men attack the house. Bash and Renee end up killing the men in self-defense to find out that Maddie escaped a sophisticated trafficking ring, and those guys came to recapture their top earner. We find out Maddie's sister was killed in front of her, so she sought out the one person capable of wiping out an entire criminal syndicate. Knowing retaliation is imminent, the motley crew holster up for one last round...

  • Help us to raise $$ to make this action packed movie of the year!
  • We are ready to shoot this feature, but want to snag a STAR actor to join our cast
  • With your help we can get a great name actor to bring our project to the next level.

We are PASSIONATE filmmakers ready to embark on an action packed journey of filming an independent action adventure feature film. We've got Action, Guns, Knives, Crime, Drama, Twists, Turns, Stunts, Good Guys (and Gals), Bad Guys (and Gals), Lights, Camera, and did we mention.. ACTION!  We are just missing one thing - a STAR name to be our super villain.  We have a great story, cast and crew all ready to go. We are asking for your teamwork in making this the indie action movie of the year. We are a super motivated experienced team of filmmakers, read to bring you and the world the next great indie action film. We've got a cast of talented actors and a crew of experienced stunt actors to bring the drama and to bring the ACTION. It's a Fast paced action adventure that will keep you glued to the screen from start to finish. Bas Ass Hero Man, check. Pretty Girls, check. Ruthless Bad Guys, check. Guns, check. Ammo, check. Glass bottles to bash over some heads, check:

What We Need & What You Get

OK folks, here's how it rolls:

  • It turns out Movie Stars don't work for free.. or even cheap.. we don't blame them, but ..
  • BUT we are offering a ton of super fun ways you can get involved in this project ! Yes, we ultimately need your dollars,,, but in exchange we are offering some super perks. Yes, you CAN be in our movie, yes you CAN dictate how the bad guys gets killed on page 23, yes, you CAN even be a costume designer for the day. .. and many many more perks where that came from. 
  • We are already FUNDED to shoot this feature, so this movie IS GOING TO BE MADE! so no risk there kids. But the more fun you want to have in exchange for giving us your dollars, the more movie STAR we can get in our movie. How bout we make it a big one, eh?

The Impact

We CAN'T do this without you, yes YOU:

  • We have a great story
  • We've got a great director, cinematographer, stunt crew, and:
  • We have a great CAST of talented actors that have been preparing for months for their roles and are ready to rock this. They are beautiful, and some are not beautiful, but we will let you decide which is which. 

 

Risks & Challenges

What are the risks you say? Too good to be true you say? Well think again

  • ALL of our perks are ready to go - this isn't a campaign where if we don't get X dollars than nobody gets squat.. nope, this movie is BEING MADE, so all perks WILL be honored and filled. Many of the perks have to do with being involved in the film making, so there's no waiting to receive the perk, it's gonna happen right now so we can use you input to make this movie.  (tentative October, 2020 production start date) We have a 2 step plan to guarantee we all have fun here. it's simple.
  • step 1. MAKE MOVIE.  
  • step 2. there is no step 2.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize you may not be able to contribute at the 10 million dollar level, but:

  • You can PLEASE help to share this campaign , we LOVE you for it!
  • If you happen to know or ARE a movie star just come on over and be in our movie. 

And that's all there is to it.

 

THE TEAM

Here's more juicy info on who is involved with making this film::

story:
Welcome to the Indiegogo page for Fast Forward to Forever! Fast Forward to Forever is created by Dylan Martin (director/editor) and Brendan Carretero (writer/producer). The two have collaborated on several short-form projects together since meeting at California Polytechnic State University-San Luis Obispo, where they both attended college.

TRIGGER WARNING!

**NOTE: Private Screening will be a Digital Private Screening


Mental health challenges have been at an all-time high since the onset of Covid-19. Dylan and Brendan wanted to lean into this issue by creating a story that deals with themes of love and loss. What started as a single premise became so much more as they began to develop this story. They found that what they are touching on is a universal issue that goes beyond life or death. They believe they have a necessary story to tell and reach out to you with hopes of helping them create the best version of their story possible.

 

LOGLINE

When his significant other passes away due to suicide, a boy finds himself remembering the past and asking, "What could I have done differently?"

 

DIRECTOR’S STATEMENT

Every person in this world experiences at least two things in their life - love and loss. Fast Forward to Forever is a story that tackles the grieving process and the questions we ask ourselves as humans when someone passes away. To those of you who have found yourself asking “why didn’t I spend my time with this person more wisely?” or “what could I have done differently?” this is a story to you. This is a story that takes place within the context of suicide, but tackles a feeling that is universal. When my father passed away a few years ago, I constantly asked myself if I spent the time I had with him wisely. I always asked myself why I didn’t do more with the time we had together.

 

Eventually, I came to understand that this type of thinking was not allowing me to move on and acknowledge my circumstances for what they were. I had to look at both ends of the spectrum. I realized that this concept goes beyond human comprehension of love and loss, but really ties into this idea of “forever.” We want viewers to know that memories have worth and that people, whether they are here in the present or gone, have worth. The love we experience for those around us is that “forever.” The butterfly motif in our story is a physical representation of that “forever.” It is a symbol of hope. It is a sign that there will be brighter days. It is a sign that there is light at the end of the tunnel. I believe anyone who has experienced loss in their lives, will understand the themes that we are trying to unravel in this film.

 

 

CHARACTERS 

Josh is a wallflower-type character who doesn’t seem too great at making close friends. We picture him as a socially awkward kid who lives a pretty stable lifestyle with few distractions. He is a reserved and shy person with few interests, one of them being music. He is pulled into Anna’s world as he recognizes someone who feels alone too.

Anna is a 17-year-old girl who, like many young adults, struggles with feelings of depression. She not only feels different from other people, but her sense of isolation and sadness does not get any better at home. We picture her as someone who was naturally attractive, but still could not help but feel isolated from the world around her. She is the girl that nobody could see and Josh is the only boy who could see her. When she commits suicide, it leaves Josh in a state of confusion as he recalls their memories together.



 

 

Mr.Miller is a middle-aged substitute teacher with good intentions. He’s that one favorite substitute teacher you had in high school. He is a minor character, but his slip-up is the catalyst for Josh to try and recall the signs he may have missed when Anna was here. We picture him as someone who is on the stockier side and possibly a man of many talents outside of his teaching career. His jubilant nature lays in high contrast to the emotions he evokes from Josh.

THE BUTTERFLY

As we travel through the past and present from Josh’s perspective, the butterfly serves as a metaphor that adds a deeper layer to this story. While it reminds him of his memories with Anna, it also is connected to the ideas associated with The Butterfly Project. The Butterfly Project is an avoidance technique aimed to prevent self-harm. It involves a person drawing a butterfly on their arms, legs, or hands to remind them of the important people in their lives. 

THE WORLD

Fast Forward to Forever takes place in a suburban town near a large city. The landscape is reminiscent of areas like Minneapolis or areas of Delaware. Our artistic style lays more on the realistic side of 2D animation. Our world will consist of a color palette containing purples, blues, pinks, and oranges while saturation levels will mirror the emotions of our characters. The color of our world will be essential in describing the nature of what they are feeling. Below are some visual development art pieces that may give you a sense of the style and color palette of the film.




 

THE TEAM

 

Meet the Director/Editor: Dylan Martin is a director and editor based in Los Angeles, California. His career in the film industry began as an animatic assistant on Disney films such as the live-action Lady and the Tramp and The Little Mermaid. He later found a strong interest in editing and segued in that direction. He started his career in editorial on the film Happiest Season and is currently an assistant editor on the animated film, Groove Tails. With a strong passion for storytelling and a love for animation, he began developing Fast Forward to Forever with Brendan Carretero in 2020. 

 

Meet the Producer/Writer: Brendan Carretero is a writer and producer based in Los Angeles, CA. He is a graduate of California Polytechnic State University where he began to translate his love for telling stories into words on the page. He has worked a variety of roles within the film industry on titles such as Army of the Dead, Thunder Force, and The Host App. With a passion for stories that tackle socially relevant issues, he is driven to help continue to create films that reflect real life.

 

Meet the Artists:

Wan Lee   Hannah Eberhardt  Maddy Mizusaki   Winona Noronha  Grey Han

 

Bien Lacurom     Braden Deal    Sean Swaby

 

BUDGET 

While making movies is an expensive endeavor, animation can be even more costly. It is one thing to determine the ideal budget for your project and another to note what is actually within reach. Regardless of such circumstances, we are determined to raise the funds needed to tell our story in the best way possible. Animated films cost money and it is a goal of ours to pay every single person that works for us something. We have worked on projects in the past where we were not compensated, and we want to avoid this. There is a steep cost in getting all of the necessary departments (story, visual development, animation) paid.  With this campaign, we will spend 60 days trying to reach our first goal of $12,500. 

We want to be fully transparent with our plans, so we have included a breakdown below that shows exactly how we will allocate the funds:

RISKS

We are aware that $12,500 is definitely not a small sum of money. With a budget of this number comes risks. We are aware of that and we have already planned ahead. If we are not able to hit our budgeting goals through crowdfunding, this film will still get made. We have already attracted interest in our project and we believe that the positive momentum will continue. This is a necessary story, this is an important story, and we will make sure the world sees it.

SCHEDULE

The schedule provided below is our ideal timeline. We hope to have a fully formed package ready for animation by June of this year. We have some really talented artists onboard who have been working closely with us since the beginning of the year. With this goal in mind, we hope to have the animation completed by October, so that post-production will be finished in time for us to submit for most of our top choice Oscar-qualifying festivals. We are shooting for the stars with this project. We think we have the potential to go the distance. It will take the necessary funds to hit these goals in a timely manner. 

Visual Development complete -- June 2021

Animation Complete -- October 2021

Post-Production Complete -- December 2021

Private Screening -- PENDING

Other Rewards -- November 2021 

 

JOIN OUR COMMUNITY

It takes a village! We would love for you to be part of this journey with us! Please feel free to share this campaign with your friends and loved ones, and we appreciate your support. You can also see more information at Fastforwardtoforevermovie.com as well as on Instagram and Facebook. 

We will regularly post updates on these accounts, and we can’t wait to show you what we have in store!
story_txt:
Welcome to the Indiegogo page for Fast Forward to Forever! Fast Forward to Forever is created by Dylan Martin (director/editor) and Brendan Carretero (writer/producer). The two have collaborated on several short-form projects together since meeting at California Polytechnic State University-San Luis Obispo, where they both attended college.TRIGGER WARNING!**NOTE: Private Screening will be a Digital Private ScreeningMental health challenges have been at an all-time high since the onset of Covid-19. Dylan and Brendan wanted to lean into this issue by creating a story that deals with themes of love and loss. What started as a single premise became so much more as they began to develop this story. They found that what they are touching on is a universal issue that goes beyond life or death. They believe they have a necessary story to tell and reach out to you with hopes of helping them create the best version of their story possible. LOGLINEWhen his significant other passes away due to suicide, a boy finds himself remembering the past and asking, "What could I have done differently?" DIRECTOR’S STATEMENTEvery person in this world experiences at least two things in their life - love and loss. Fast Forward to Forever is a story that tackles the grieving process and the questions we ask ourselves as humans when someone passes away. To those of you who have found yourself asking “why didn’t I spend my time with this person more wisely?” or “what could I have done differently?” this is a story to you. This is a story that takes place within the context of suicide, but tackles a feeling that is universal. When my father passed away a few years ago, I constantly asked myself if I spent the time I had with him wisely. I always asked myself why I didn’t do more with the time we had together. Eventually, I came to understand that this type of thinking was not allowing me to move on and acknowledge my circumstances for what they were. I had to look at both ends of the spectrum. I realized that this concept goes beyond human comprehension of love and loss, but really ties into this idea of “forever.” We want viewers to know that memories have worth and that people, whether they are here in the present or gone, have worth. The love we experience for those around us is that “forever.” The butterfly motif in our story is a physical representation of that “forever.” It is a symbol of hope. It is a sign that there will be brighter days. It is a sign that there is light at the end of the tunnel. I believe anyone who has experienced loss in their lives, will understand the themes that we are trying to unravel in this film.  CHARACTERS Josh is a wallflower-type character who doesn’t seem too great at making close friends. We picture him as a socially awkward kid who lives a pretty stable lifestyle with few distractions. He is a reserved and shy person with few interests, one of them being music. He is pulled into Anna’s world as he recognizes someone who feels alone too.Anna is a 17-year-old girl who, like many young adults, struggles with feelings of depression. She not only feels different from other people, but her sense of isolation and sadness does not get any better at home. We picture her as someone who was naturally attractive, but still could not help but feel isolated from the world around her. She is the girl that nobody could see and Josh is the only boy who could see her. When she commits suicide, it leaves Josh in a state of confusion as he recalls their memories together.  Mr.Miller is a middle-aged substitute teacher with good intentions. He’s that one favorite substitute teacher you had in high school. He is a minor character, but his slip-up is the catalyst for Josh to try and recall the signs he may have missed when Anna was here. We picture him as someone who is on the stockier side and possibly a man of many talents outside of his teaching career. His jubilant nature lays in high contrast to the emotions he evokes from Josh.THE BUTTERFLYAs we travel through the past and present from Josh’s perspective, the butterfly serves as a metaphor that adds a deeper layer to this story. While it reminds him of his memories with Anna, it also is connected to the ideas associated with The Butterfly Project. The Butterfly Project is an avoidance technique aimed to prevent self-harm. It involves a person drawing a butterfly on their arms, legs, or hands to remind them of the important people in their lives. THE WORLDFast Forward to Forever takes place in a suburban town near a large city. The landscape is reminiscent of areas like Minneapolis or areas of Delaware. Our artistic style lays more on the realistic side of 2D animation. Our world will consist of a color palette containing purples, blues, pinks, and oranges while saturation levels will mirror the emotions of our characters. The color of our world will be essential in describing the nature of what they are feeling. Below are some visual development art pieces that may give you a sense of the style and color palette of the film.

 THE TEAM Meet the Director/Editor: Dylan Martin is a director and editor based in Los Angeles, California. His career in the film industry began as an animatic assistant on Disney films such as the live-action Lady and the Tramp and The Little Mermaid. He later found a strong interest in editing and segued in that direction. He started his career in editorial on the film Happiest Season and is currently an assistant editor on the animated film, Groove Tails. With a strong passion for storytelling and a love for animation, he began developing Fast Forward to Forever with Brendan Carretero in 2020.  Meet the Producer/Writer: Brendan Carretero is a writer and producer based in Los Angeles, CA. He is a graduate of California Polytechnic State University where he began to translate his love for telling stories into words on the page. He has worked a variety of roles within the film industry on titles such as Army of the Dead, Thunder Force, and The Host App. With a passion for stories that tackle socially relevant issues, he is driven to help continue to create films that reflect real life. Meet the Artists:Wan Lee   Hannah Eberhardt  Maddy Mizusaki   Winona Noronha  Grey Han Bien Lacurom     Braden Deal    Sean Swaby BUDGET While making movies is an expensive endeavor, animation can be even more costly. It is one thing to determine the ideal budget for your project and another to note what is actually within reach. Regardless of such circumstances, we are determined to raise the funds needed to tell our story in the best way possible. Animated films cost money and it is a goal of ours to pay every single person that works for us something. We have worked on projects in the past where we were not compensated, and we want to avoid this. There is a steep cost in getting all of the necessary departments (story, visual development, animation) paid.  With this campaign, we will spend 60 days trying to reach our first goal of $12,500. We want to be fully transparent with our plans, so we have included a breakdown below that shows exactly how we will allocate the funds:RISKSWe are aware that $12,500 is definitely not a small sum of money. With a budget of this number comes risks. We are aware of that and we have already planned ahead. If we are not able to hit our budgeting goals through crowdfunding, this film will still get made. We have already attracted interest in our project and we believe that the positive momentum will continue. This is a necessary story, this is an important story, and we will make sure the world sees it.SCHEDULEThe schedule provided below is our ideal timeline. We hope to have a fully formed package ready for animation by June of this year. We have some really talented artists onboard who have been working closely with us since the beginning of the year. With this goal in mind, we hope to have the animation completed by October, so that post-production will be finished in time for us to submit for most of our top choice Oscar-qualifying festivals. We are shooting for the stars with this project. We think we have the potential to go the distance. It will take the necessary funds to hit these goals in a timely manner. Visual Development complete -- June 2021Animation Complete -- October 2021Post-Production Complete -- December 2021Private Screening -- PENDINGOther Rewards -- November 2021  JOIN OUR COMMUNITYIt takes a village! We would love for you to be part of this journey with us! Please feel free to share this campaign with your friends and loved ones, and we appreciate your support. You can also see more information at Fastforwardtoforevermovie.com as well as on Instagram and Facebook. We will regularly post updates on these accounts, and we can’t wait to show you what we have in store!

story:
Short Summary

I Took A Nap And I Miss You is a student film production; A coming-of-age, drama-comedy mockumentary about a family of three - a mother and two daughters - all operating on what-ifs and varying struggles with intimacy. We are a team feverish with passion but lacking in resources. In full truth, we are dying to make this project a reality and in the best way it could be - the best performances for the best heart, the right things and places for the best energy - but we do not have enough money. Your contribution would mean bringing our dreams closer to us, and hopefully would be something you'd find joy to witness. 

 

Synopsis

With the recent death of her husband Luke, Liz juggles her emotions while navigating through that of her two daughters’ – making sure that they’re okay in the world, and that she’s okay. Liz’s teen daughter Gigi stands at the cusp of a potential romance and attempts to gain revelation about her own ambiguous feelings, unsure if what she's discovered of herself is all it is. Stacy finds companionship within an imaginary boyfriend, Nicky, getting bullied for it, bringing up concern for the family.

 

Director's Statement

There had been a death in their family, but I would like to challenge the idea of major events in a person’s life affecting a person’s psyche and leaving a permanent mark – is that always the case, is it so A equals to B or is it possible that more trivial things could lead to B? It’s become too automatic to assume in the world we live in today, that certain things are explained by certain events. Stacy has an imaginary boyfriend and is getting bullied for it, but where did it come from, and does it matter? Are things only real if they exist socially? The malfunctions of intimacy are classic motherfuckers in anyone's lives, I think it a challenge to portray it without overemphasizing and with a touch of warmth, just enough of everything to be relatable and human. 

 

Where Your Funds Will Go

The performance and the chemistry between the cast is paramount to the success of our film. The funding will help us in paying each key actor reasonably well to ensure the best acting we can get. 

It will also help us to pay for location permit and production design in the right house, to create the unique, quirky yet homely setting for our characters to engage with in this heartwarming story. 

The rest of the funding will mostly go into food (to feed our hardworking cast and crew) and transport (we have to transport huge bulky camera, lighting equipments and the crew through rented lorries/big vans).

Any excess of the money donated, should there be, will be used wisely to enhance our collective creative vision on screen. We deeply appreciate EVERY DOLLAR that you donate to us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can take a phone screenshot of the main page of our crowdfunding site, share it on your Instagram story, ask for support, and tag our Instagram page at @itookanapandimissyou, finally indicate that the crowdfunding website is linked in our bio (or yours)!

story:
Short Summary

"bef0re"  is a 10 min science fiction short film, about two code programmers working under a tech company called "0" where they have to run coding tests on a time machine prototype that causes time loops that they suffer the consequences of in real time. The two code programmers and fellow friends "Rob" and "Aaron" volunteer to take part in this mission, and it doesn't take long before they realise they've bitten off more than they can chew. The time loop resets after a limited interval; a time frame in which Aaron and Rob have to do their work in, before the interval resets, which causes lapses in the memories of the two characters, where they vaguely remember details of their mission.  Both of them run on different times according to the strength and qualities of their brain synapses and carry a timer device that has a countdown till the interval resets so they can leave ample time to sleep, because being unconscious is the only way to survive a time reset.  Once one of them wakes up, the other one has to carry out a procedure of checking if the other person is stable and run some health checks, after that their job is to remind them of their cause and why they are there in the first place , and then go off to sleep before their time runs out. 

 

The Team:

"bef0re"  consists of a group of people from different backgrounds and unique sensibilities which will hopefully enable us to create magic together:

1. Producer: Oscar Aitchison 

"Hello i’m Oscar Aitchison. I wanted to get on board with this project because the script really spoke to me as a huge fan of sci-fi. I write plenty of sci-fi related scripts as it is and i thought Arij had really nailed a complex yet achievable narrative with well placed ambition. I can’t wait to start the process and make the incredible story a reality!”

2. Cinematographer: Grayson Moody

"What I appreciate about cinema is it’s ability to tell simple stories in the most complex of ways. Some of my favourite films are the ones that despite the grand settings, moving score and complex plots, it’s the little messages inside that give the spectacle meaning. That’s what drew me to "bef0re".  At its core, this film is just a story of friendship and trust between mates, and I’m very excited to start work on translating that to screen."

3. First AC: Chloe Butcher

'I'm really excited to work on this film as sci-fi is a genre that I love, and time travel is a really interesting concept that we can be really creative with".

4. Composer: Alessandro Giovanetto

"Hi! My name is Alessandro Giovanetto and I am a film composer and guitarist. I am so grateful to Aaraj for deciding to have me as a composer for his film "Before". It is an exciting project and the intricacies of the plot as well as the insights of the main characters are really inspiring and I cannot wait to experiment with the sonic possibilities to support this story!  Since the first time upon meeting Aaraj, I realised how much potential he has as a storyteller and director, and how much he was already able to inspire me in a first pre production session we had was surprising! I can't wait to see how this will turn out!"

 

What We Need & What You Get:

This is a final year University project, and as students we have very limited resources to pull this film off on our own.

1. Location:

The pandemic hasn't made things easier for us  and we had a cyber attack incident in our University that caused all the computer servers of the university to crash, making it hard for us to film on campus as our film revolves around the characters using a computer and interacting with the interface, because of this we will have to look for locations outside of our University where we will have to pay a daily location fee. 

2. Transport:

We will have to arrange a van to transport the filmmaking equipment from one location to the other, this will cost transportation fee for a van to bring the equipment back and forth for four days of filming. 

3. Catering: 

Fresh food and refreshments are a vital component on a running set, for the crew to function efficiently they need to be able to nourish themselves to keep up with the rough regiment and 10 hour work day, in order to do that we will be hiring a catering service that will be able to provide the cast and crew with nutritious meals. 

4. Cast and Crew fee:

We will be using the services of extremely skilled crew members to bring this film to life, which includes the actors as well as a professional composer, we will have to pay for the actors travel and food expenses as well as pay the composer for his hard work on the score of the film. 

5. Visual Effects:

The film requires some special effects work on sequences where the character are asleep and we have to create a sequence in which we showcase an iteration of what people see when they sleep, which is spectrum of colours merging and streaks of colours moving, for this we will have to hire a special effects designer to make that possible. 

6. Time machine Prop: The time machine prop will be made by the engineering students in our University and funding will be needed to get the appropriate materials required to construct a time machine. 

7. Festival Submission: We will be submitting the finished film to many film festivals which will require a submission fee. 

What you'll get: 

We have a wide array of perks waiting for the people that claim them, Every bit of your donations will be spent on the film and you will be able to see that on the screen, when the film is done.  The perks are named after iterations which are different layers of coding and are a main aspect and component of the mechanics of our film. 

1. iteration 1: You will get a signed copy of the script

2. iteration 2: You will get two different signed posters of the film. 

3. iteration 3: You will get a digital version of the film with director's commentary. 

4. iteration 4: You will get digital album of the soundtracks of the film ranging from electronic to synth music and a cavalcade of other experimental music. 

5. iteration 0 : You will get executive producer credit which will appear at the end of the film. 

 

The Impact:

Your donation will help us make this unconventional genre film possible,  it will allow us to make a cerebral story and encourage other filmmakers and give them confidence to use this platform to help them to make "out - of- the box" stories that would be otherwise challenging for independent filmmakers to kickstart. 

 

Risks & Challenges:

the obvious and prominent challenge is the pandemic that has abrupted our schedule and logistics quite a bit as well as the cyber attack on the network servers of the university has made it hard for us to be authorised to use any computer rooms or locations in the University which propels us to seek out locations in which we will have to pay location fees as well as transport equipment back and forth. We will also follow all the precautionary protocols needed to film in this pandemic which will include checking the temperature of the cast and crew members, wearing masks at all times, spraying and cleaning the equipment with anti bacteria. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, that is absolutely fine, we would like to appreciate your help in other ways if possible:

  • SPREAD THE WORD!!!! Please follow us on our socials and pass on the information of the campaign to your friends and family. 
  • Share the campaign through Indiegogo share tool. 
  • Follow us on Instagram: @bef0refilm, on Twitter follow director @arijmir and on Facebook follow the director arijsnan, who will be posting information regarding the campaign and it's progress.

story:
Hello, my name is Brad Springs and I have worked in our around the live music industry in some capacity for the better part of 25 years. Sound engineer, venue owner, talent buyer, booking agent, band manager. festival promoter, and writer for music magazines. There is not much in the music industry that I have not taken to task. I have never seen any situation in my entire career that concerns me more than the times we are going through right now with Covid-19 from a live music venue perspective and certainly from the artists perspective who in some cases make their living playing live shows.

We through this project hope to document the struggles that an entire industry from the venue perspective and from working musicians perspective just how dire the situation is. In many instances working musicians are considered self employed and do not qualify for unemployment, did not get stimulus relief and in some cases the same goes for the venues. Many of which are being forced to only be open in limited capacity to the point of it not being worth being open, and some based upon their liquor license type are not allowed to be open at all due to government mandates while other businesses can remain open if only in a limited capacity and at least generate some sort of revenue. 

Hopefully we can impress in some way upon our elected leaders to take a harder look at how their polices effect everyone involved in supporting live music and the arts in general. Not just musicians, not just the venues but in other fields as well. Sound engineers, road crews, film and video production workers. All just forced to sit home and not know where there next paycheck will come from. Until?...Until? Sporting event venues/teams are beginning to move toward re-open at limited capacities, in some cases depending on the the size of the venue limited capacity may be 30,40, maybe 50,000 fans. But a live music venue that may normally be a 300 seat venue can't hold events with 150 people if considered a bar due to liquor license type? Just too risky? Alcohol involved. Well every professional sporting event I have ever attended has beer concessions, almost every restaurant chain in the United States that isn't considered fast food, and some that are considered fast food, serve alcohol. 

While we are all living through a situation that we have never been through before at least in most of our lifetimes. And absolutely none of us should take any of it lightly, wear masks, practice social distancing. But to single out one industry the one and only industry that cannot be open in any capacity "bars/music venues" and not trust the owners to do the right thing, for the safety of the patrons, the musicians,  and themselves is absurd. But that is where we are at it seems.  This project is hopefully not only a way to spread the word hopefully to the world, far and wide and force our elected officials to not marginalize any tax paying hard working citizens they were elected to represent. But also, since a great deal of us are stuck at home in limbo and running out of content to watch we can hopefully entertain you. The documentary film will not only feature interviews and personal insight but live music performances (filmed in a forced to be closed to the public venue) as well live streaming viewing opportunities during the making of process.
story_txt: Hello, my name is Brad Springs and I have worked in our around the live music industry in some capacity for the better part of 25 years. Sound engineer, venue owner, talent buyer, booking agent, band manager. festival promoter, and writer for music magazines. There is not much in the music industry that I have not taken to task. I have never seen any situation in my entire career that concerns me more than the times we are going through right now with Covid-19 from a live music venue perspective and certainly from the artists perspective who in some cases make their living playing live shows.We through this project hope to document the struggles that an entire industry from the venue perspective and from working musicians perspective just how dire the situation is. In many instances working musicians are considered self employed and do not qualify for unemployment, did not get stimulus relief and in some cases the same goes for the venues. Many of which are being forced to only be open in limited capacity to the point of it not being worth being open, and some based upon their liquor license type are not allowed to be open at all due to government mandates while other businesses can remain open if only in a limited capacity and at least generate some sort of revenue. Hopefully we can impress in some way upon our elected leaders to take a harder look at how their polices effect everyone involved in supporting live music and the arts in general. Not just musicians, not just the venues but in other fields as well. Sound engineers, road crews, film and video production workers. All just forced to sit home and not know where there next paycheck will come from. Until?...Until? Sporting event venues/teams are beginning to move toward re-open at limited capacities, in some cases depending on the the size of the venue limited capacity may be 30,40, maybe 50,000 fans. But a live music venue that may normally be a 300 seat venue can't hold events with 150 people if considered a bar due to liquor license type? Just too risky? Alcohol involved. Well every professional sporting event I have ever attended has beer concessions, almost every restaurant chain in the United States that isn't considered fast food, and some that are considered fast food, serve alcohol. While we are all living through a situation that we have never been through before at least in most of our lifetimes. And absolutely none of us should take any of it lightly, wear masks, practice social distancing. But to single out one industry the one and only industry that cannot be open in any capacity "bars/music venues" and not trust the owners to do the right thing, for the safety of the patrons, the musicians,  and themselves is absurd. But that is where we are at it seems.  This project is hopefully not only a way to spread the word hopefully to the world, far and wide and force our elected officials to not marginalize any tax paying hard working citizens they were elected to represent. But also, since a great deal of us are stuck at home in limbo and running out of content to watch we can hopefully entertain you. The documentary film will not only feature interviews and personal insight but live music performances (filmed in a forced to be closed to the public venue) as well live streaming viewing opportunities during the making of process.

story:
A Short Summary

We are a group of film students from York st John University and we are looking to secure funding for our upcoming short film "Baker Street". The film is a comedy focusing on the relations between Sherlock Holmes and his neighbour. 

Logline

After moving into Baker Street, a young man begins to question his neighbour’s antics when the police are constantly knocking at the door and troubled people are mistaking his house for his neighbours. This is to be expected when moving next door to the infamous detective, Sherlock Holmes.   

How will the funds be used?

The funds will go towards just about everything. We will use them for acting, locations, travel, costumes, catering, props and equipment. If we get enough funding and our short film is a success we will also be able to submit it to film festivals that require paid entry. We have already been given a small sum from our university to cover some basic expenses but to really make this great, we need a little extra funding.

Your contribution will help us massively as it will increase the production value of our film and it let us get our foot in the door in this highly competitive industry. 

If you want to support our project but cant afford to donate, feel free to share it and tell others. Any contribution helps a lot.

story:
Author, Activist, Artist, & Mental  Health Advocate... The highs of Jermaine J. Williams are truly impressive. But the challenging & troubled lows are what made his life complicated. Ravished by cocaine and alcoholism, the once-promising rapper found himself fighting just to stay alive. When inpatient rehab & counseling didn’t work, the thirteen-year addiction began to take a toll on him. To rid himself of addiction, every option was on the table, unfortunately, suicide was one of those options. Before the thought out attempt could take place, Jermaine planned to visit a church to make peace with his creator. During the praise and worship service, something began to happen. “Something was going on over there… something powerful” is how the praise and worship leader described his recollection of that Sunday morning. Whatever it was, it brought an end to an addiction that troubled Jermaine for thirteen years. Going into his fifth year of sobriety, this groundbreaking documentary explores the struggle of addiction, while telling the extraordinary story of Jermaine J. Williams. A story of addiction to redemption.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Currently, the documentary is in rough draft form, & is near preproduction completion. In post-production, we will re-edit the documentary, revise the sound quality, add interviews and commentary, enhance the picture and make the necessary color correction to make the product more industry-ready.

We have AMAZING perks for each level of donations!!

The Impact

  Our vision is to educate the world of the challenges of  Substance Abuse while giving hope to those who are experiencing the same struggle. Jermaine J. Williams's battle with substance abuse mirrors a lot of addicts worldwide. Showing him accomplishing five years of sobriety in rough circumstances will deliver much-needed hope.

story:
Who Am I?

My name is Colton Beckwith. I'm a 13-year-old student filmmaker from Redding, California. I have had an interest in filmmaking since I was little, and I directed my first short film to be submitted to festivals last year. I recently co-wrote a fifteen page screenplay with my brother titled Let's Go Camping, about three unprepared city teenagers who decide to go on a camping trip, resulting in a disastrous trip full of comedic adventure.

Production Needs

This is where you, our backers, come in. There are several production expenses for this film with which we need your assistance! They are as follows:

  • A Dell Windows 10 Desktop Computer ($230.00) 
  • A small jib arm ($124.93)
  • Two 50' audio extension cables ($19.28)
  • On-set food ($100)
  • Gasoline ($100)
  • Bear suit ($359.89)
  • Film Festival Submission Fees ($100)
  • Additional Fees/Reserves

Total: $1,200

Perks

By donating any amount you will automatically receive credit as an IndieGoGo backer in the end credits of the film, as well as on the film's website. If you donate to this project, you will receive a reward as follows:

  • ($10.00 +) You will receive credit in the film under "Special Thanks".
  • ($20.00 +) You will receive a FREE ticket to a film festival screening of Let's Go Camping  near you. Note: This may be a paid online festival if necessary.
  • ($50.00 +) You will receive a Let's Go Camping baseball cap.
  • ($100.00 +) You will receive a Let's Go Camping t-shirt. 
  • ($500.00 +) You will receive a credit as an executive producer.
